name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: I declare resumed the session of the European Parliament adjourned on Thursday, 23 July 2020.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: Ladies and gentlemen, I welcome the Members present and those connected on the web.  As is evident to everyone, we are still inside the COVID-19 emergency. We had hoped, with the summer break, to return to normality, but we found that our countries are still affected by the virus.  The progression of contagion has resumed in many of our territories and has prompted national governments to take containment measures.  That is why, on the basis of the information provided by the health services and the French authorities, I have taken the decision, with regret, not to hold the plenary session in Strasbourg in September.  I would like to thank the chairmen of the political groups for their support for this difficult decision and for expressing to the Conference of Presidents their full support for my decision to reinstate the Strasbourg session as soon as the health situation in the city and the security conditions allow us to return.  I am grateful to the French authorities for understanding the spirit of this decision and for their continued cooperation in these difficult months. On behalf of all Members, I would like to extend a warm greeting to the mayor and the citizens of Strasbourg, pending our return, which we hope will happen as soon as possible.  Ladies and gentlemen, I have received a report from many of you of a case of a Slovak citizen, Jozef Chovanec, who died after being held in custody at Charleroi airport in February 2018.  I would like to express my solidarity and solidarity with the family, with his loved ones, with his friends, and to emphasise once again that respect for human rights and the rule of law is a central value for the European Union. We support the demand for truth and call for clarity on who is responsible.  The European Parliament's Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs has already been involved in this case and Parliament will, of course, follow developments.

name: Manon AUBRY
text: Mr President, I would like to address all of you to express our disgust at the abject caricature of my colleague Danièle Obono, elected from the French National Assembly, who was represented as a chained slave in the far-right newspaper Values Today. This nauseating drawing, oozing from vile racism and sexism, must make us react here collectively. The violence of this attack is obviously first of all personal, with a desire to humiliate an elected representative of the Republic because of her skin color, but it is also a political message legitimising the racism and discrimination suffered on a daily basis by millions of black Europeans. The violence of images and words leads to the violence of acts, and the Council of Europe has just alerted us to their worrying upsurge across Europe. So from Parliament, we say it very clearly: it is no longer possible to stand idly by in the face of the trivialisation of uninhibited racism. Don't let anything pass, don't give in an inch, don't look down. Our role is to take a stand, as we did a few weeks ago by voting to recognize the slave trade as a crime against humanity. Let us now live up to the present by condemning in the strongest terms this racism that is bursting before our eyes.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: – Mr President, this Parliament is going to debate the situation in the refugee camp in Moria on Thursday, and rightfully so as the situation has dramatically deteriorated after fires broke out last week. There are thousands of people without shelter and without clean water, many of them children. It is clear that we have to act. The European Parliament is actually ready to act. It is just the Council that is blocking. Under this precondition, I believe it is absolutely unacceptable that we debate this situation without the Council being present. So I would like you, Mr President, to make sure that the Council has to be here when we discuss the situation in Moria.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Mr President, I speak on behalf of many MEPs over political divisions. We kindly ask you to consider, during the next October part-session, our question referring to the human rights situation in Iran, especially political prisoners sentenced to death. Unfortunately, the situation deteriorated since our earlier request: Navid Afkari has already been executed. We kindly ask you to consider this request.

name: Nicolaus FEST
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the I refer to Article 11 and Article 22(5) and Annex III to the Interinstitutional Agreement on the Transparency Register. I recommend this, because it is not acceptable for people who commit criminal acts to also be running around Parliament with lobby cards. I would ask the Bureau to decide on this at the next sitting.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the joint debate on the interim report on the proposal for a Council decision on the finding that there is a clear risk of serious breach of the rule of law by the Republic of Poland (2017/0360R(NLE)))- Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Rapporteur: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (A9-0138/2020) and - the question with request for an oral reply to the Commission: LGBTI-free zones in Poland in the Lenford Network case, presented by Marc Angel, Maria Walsh, Fabio Massimo Castaldo, Terry Reintke, Malin Björk, Kira Marie Peter-Hansen, Pernille Weiss, Billy Kelleher, Isabel Carvalhais, Pernando Barrena Arza, Sophia in 't Veld, Marianne Vind, Sirpa Pietikäinen, Dietmar Köster, Monika Vana, Daniel Freund, Frédérique Ries, Francisco Guerreiro, Nathalie Loiseau, Frances Fitzgerald, Birgit Sippel, Robert Biedroń, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, Vera Tax, Evelyne Gebhardt, Arba Kokalari, Petra De Sutter, Grace O'Sullivan, Gwendoline Delbos-Corfield, Radka Maxová, Heidi Hautala, Evelyn Regner , Rosa D'Amato, Aurore Lalucq, Hilde Vautmans, Pierre Karleskind, Evin Incir, Pina Picierno, Antoni Comín i Oliveres, Johan Danielsson, Magdalena Adamowicz, Diana Riba i Giner , Sandro Gozi, Brando Benifei, Mónica Silvana González, Ernest Urtasun, Kim Van Sparrentak, Alice Kuhnke, Rasmus Andresen, Marie Toussaint, Milan Brglez, Karen Melchior, Chrysoula Zakharopoulou, Eleonora Evi, Sylwia Spurek, Manuel Bompard, Isabel Santos, Jeroen Lenaers and Delara Burkhardt (O-000042/2020) (B9-0017/2020).

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Rapporteur. - Mr President, Vice-President Jourová, if, among other international and supranational organisations, all European institutions, including the Commission and the European Parliament, but also the Council of Europe, the Venice Commission, think tanks dedicated to human rights, as well as the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe ( the OSCE – and its Parliamentary Assembly, have devoted opinions and resolutions , over and over again, to Poland, there must be some reason. Because they have expressed concern about a Poland, which we still remember in its recent accession to the European project, moving further and further away from European values. And, of course, that reason cannot have to do with the surreal explanation we've heard more than once that this is a leftist conspiracy. It's ridiculous.  The reason is serious. We are talking about an abrupt sequence of initiatives for institutional and legislative reforms, which have clearly raised the threatening news of a certain risk of serious violation of the founding values of the European Union enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on European Union. And that is the assumption on which the European Parliament launched the procedure referred to in Article 7, which is now at the Council table. And indeed, it is very worrying that sequence, which has been described more than once as constitutional breakdown, of constitutional collapse of the architecture of the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights in Poland. Because to undermine the founding values of the European Union, democracy and rights in any Member State of the European Union — the case of Poland — is to do so throughout the European Union and is therefore an impact that undermines the credibility of the entire project of European construction, which goes directly against the project of coexistence governed by law — which is what this is all about and that is the rule of play— , with a court guaranteeing that legal order, which is the Court of Justice.  And we have found that this is resolution number ten which the European Parliament concentrates on Poland. There are seven specifically on Poland and three others on minority protection, equality and the state of fundamental rights in the European Union, which provide for very clear sections on the situation in Poland. And to be told that one more resolution might not make any difference in itself is an explanation of the extent to which this resolution is necessary and inevitable. Because Europe cannot allow neither the Resolutions of the European Parliament, nor the Commission's initiatives, nor the judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union to be systematically heard by any Member State of the European Union.  This resolution contains sixty-five paragraphs and, as chairman of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I have had the honour of being its rapporteur — the rapporteur of this European Parliament for this Resolution — and I have always tried to make it a precise, fact-in-law, factual resolution, and that it is also a resolution that flees from verbal excesses to tell exactly what are the main objects on which this sequence without precedents of abrupt institutional and legislative reforms, imposed by the majority holding the Government without anyone else in the Polish Sejm in the Polish Parliament, pose, yes, a certain risk of serious violation of the founding values of the European Union. They do so in matters of Constitutional Court, judiciary, judicial office and also disciplinary chamber, which has been classified as a Supreme Court within the Supreme Court.  These aspects relating to the separation of powers and the quality of the judiciary and the Public Prosecutor's Office in Poland — identified with the Ministry of Justice as in any other Member State of the European Union — have been hovered over as... occupation of the judiciary and abuse of the Public Prosecutor's Office. Four infringement proceedings in Article 158 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union have been initiated by the Commission. And four other judgments of the Court of Justice of the European Union have been systematically heard and ousted by the Polish authorities. Only one was partially received: that relating to the early retirement of a number of Supreme Court judges. The rest have been completely de-heard. But the Resolution also deals with other aspects, in addition to these aspects relating to the independence of the judiciary and the autonomy of the Public Prosecutor's Office in Poland. It also deals with restricted pluralism, with a serious restriction of political pluralism. It deals with rights and freedoms, which are increasingly agreed by these legislative reforms: freedom of assembly, freedom of protest, dissent and, above all, in the media; severe restriction of information pluralism. And a derogatory and threatening language towards minorities, anti-Semitic content in the last election campaign and, of course, those infamous LGBTI free zones, which have been declared by certain local administrations in Poland, which are radically incompatible with European law.  For all these reasons, this sixty-five-paragraph resolution is a resolution which seeks to be precise and contained and therefore launches a message: Commission, Council, do its job and carry out Article 7.  And I conclude by saying: this message is a message for Poland to return to the values of the Union to which it belongs, so that Poland may return to the European Union, to which it belongs. And this European Parliament is not an extraterrestrial spacecraft, nor is it any foreign power in Poland, but represents Polish citizenship, which, as it is, is European. And, therefore, Parliament defends European citizenship and Polish citizenship.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Dear colleague, I would inform you that you have now used your six minutes of speaking time, with speaking time at the end, so I cannot give you the floor at the end of the debate.

name: Marc ANGEL
text: author. – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Juan Fernando López Aguilar, for underlining that Article 7 should encompass not only the rule of law but also fundamental rights and democracy. As the co-chair of the LGBTI Intergroup, I am particularly happy that LGBTI rights in Poland are strongly addressed. The amendments the Intergroup proposed and which were adopted by the S&D rapporteur and supported by four other groups specifically target the fears and the realities that LGBTI persons are experiencing in Poland. This includes hate speech by high political officials and, more recently, police brutality during the mass arrests of LGBTI activists this summer during the Polish ‘Stonewall’. Apart from cutting EU funds under the city-twinning programmes, which we highly welcome, the Commission’s lack of action regarding LGBTI-free zones is worrying. Last April the Court of Justice of the European Union recognised in the Rete Lenford case that homophobic statements can constitute discrimination in employment. Therefore, the LGBTI Intergroup asks the Commission if it agrees that LGBTI free-zone declarations risk discriminating against LGBTI persons in employment and occupation. Will the Commission start an infringement procedure based on the EU Directive on Equal Treatment in Employment? The Polish LGBTI community needs the Commission to take stronger action. What concrete steps will the Commission take to protect it, especially when it comes to protecting human rights defenders, like the authors of the ‘Atlas of Hate’? We must keep in mind that attacks on the rights of LGBTI people are a serious threat to Fundamental Rights everywhere in our Union. Throughout the whole summer, thanks to the webinars of the LGBTI Intergroup and of Rainbow Rose, I listened to many testimonies from Polish LGBTI people. They feel neglected because of the insufficient EU action, but they still have hope and believe in strong EU support. Dear Commission, let us not disappoint them.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for having included the joint debate in the plenary agenda. Let me also thank the rapporteur, Mr López Aguilar, for his work on the report, and also the authors of the oral question. I would like to take this opportunity to present the key developments that have occurred since the last plenary debate on the situation in Poland.  Let me start with the new legislation on the judiciary of 20 December 2019, which entered into force in February this year. The Commission came to the conclusion that this law undermines the judicial independence of Polish judges and is incompatible with the primacy of EU law. In particular, it prevents Polish courts from directly applying certain provisions of EU law protecting judicial independence and from putting references for preliminary rulings on such questions to the Court of Justice. For this reason, on 28 April 2020, the Commission opened a new infringement proceeding against Poland by addressing to it a letter of formal notice. The Commission has received the reply from the Polish authorities and will soon decide on the next steps in this procedure.  As regards the new disciplinary regime for judges in Poland, upon the Commission’s request for interim measures, on 8 April 2020, the European Court of Justice ruled that Poland must immediately suspend the application of national provisions concerning the powers of the Disciplinary Chamber of the Supreme Court. The order applies until the Court has rendered its final judgment in the pending infringement procedure. Following this order, a judge of the Disciplinary Chamber referred a legal question to the Polish Constitutional Tribunal contesting the constitutionality of treaty provisions on which the order for interim measures is based. The referral is still pending with the Constitutional Tribunal.  I would like to underline that the order of the European Court of Justice is binding. It takes immediate effect and must be implemented by the Member State concerned. As made clear by the case-law of the European Court of Justice, the binding nature of the orders of the Court cannot be questioned on the basis of national laws or rulings of national courts, even on the basis of national constitutional provisions. Commissioner Reynders sent a letter to the Polish authorities regarding the implementation of the interim measures order, expressing concerns and asking for clarifications and further information. The Commission is currently analysing the reply from Poland and the situation on the ground as regards the arrangements put in place to comply with the order.  A further development is that the Disciplinary Chamber has been seized by the prosecution services in cases requesting the lifting of the judicial immunity of judges for the purpose of pursuing criminal investigations, including in cases which concern the contents of judicial decisions. On 6 June 2020, the Disciplinary Chamber rejected such a request and it is expected to re-examine this case in appeal in October. Other such cases have also been scheduled by the Disciplinary Chamber. The Commission is closely following these developments. As regards the situation in the Supreme Court, a number of further developments have taken place. On 20 April 2020, the Constitutional Tribunal held that the resolution of the Supreme Court of 23 January 2020, implementing the preliminary ruling of the European Court of Justice of 19 November 2019, was void. That resolution found that judges appointed at the request of the new National Council for the Judiciary are not permitted to adjudicate cases, and also invalidated all the rulings handed down by members of the Disciplinary Chamber. As regards the appointment of the new First President of the Supreme Court, the new law on the judiciary amended the procedure for appointment. Following the expiration of the mandate of the previous First President on 25 May 2020, the President of the Republic appointed a new First President of the Supreme Court.  There was also a relevant development relating to the execution of European Arrest Warrants with regard to Poland. In the course of this year, some Member State courts suspended the execution of the European Arrest Warrant due to further concerns regarding judicial independence in Poland. Most recently, the court of Amsterdam temporarily suspended the execution of two European Arrest Warrants to Poland submitted to it until the European Court of Justice has rendered its answers regarding two requests for a preliminary ruling. This shows that there is a real concern of mutual trust in the judiciary, which is very worrying. Finally, let me note that recently the Ministry of Justice announced that works are under way to prepare a second part of the justice reform. So far no legislative proposal is on the table. While justice reforms to improve its efficiency are always welcome, the manner in which the judiciary in Poland might be further reformed should not deepen the existing rule-of-law concerns. To conclude I regret to say that the recent developments show that the situation has not improved since the last plenary debate in February. Rule-of-law concerns still persist, and let me state clearly that the Commission will use all the instruments at its disposal to address them. This includes infringements in cases of breach of EU law, but infringements are only one tool and not all rule-of-law concerns can be addressed through infringements.  It is therefore essential also to have an open dialogue with the Polish authorities and stakeholders. Since the beginning of the mandate, the Commission has expressed its readiness for dialogue. We are open to having such a dialogue with the Polish authorities in an objective manner and with a mutual aim of solving existing problems. The upcoming first annual Rule of Law Report, covering all Member States, which the Commission will adopt soon, can be a further basis for such dialogue. This report has been prepared through a transparent process with the engagement of Member States, based on a common methodology and in an objective manner. A joint effort is needed to address the rule-of-law matters involving all the European institutions and the Commission appreciates the continuous support of the European Parliament in that respect. I also welcome the fact that the German Presidency has put on the agenda of the General Affairs Council on 22 September 2020 a state-of-play item concerning the situation of the rule of law in Poland. We also need to reinforce our rule-of-law toolbox by a mechanism in the framework of protecting the future EU budget, and the Commission made a proposal in this regard in 2018.  I am also grateful for the opportunity to react to your oral question on the situation of the LGBTI community in Poland. The Commission has received numerous petitions and letters about discriminatory language, false accusations and hate speech used in Poland. We are also fully aware of the fact that more than a hundred regions and municipalities have adopted charters, declarations and resolutions, several of which regrettably demonstrate the aim to deny fundamental rights and freedoms to LGBTI people. I want to stress the following: equality for all and equality in all of its senses is one of the major priorities of President von der Leyen. The Commission strongly condemns any form of discrimination, violence and hatred against LGBTI people and activists and is committed to fighting any form of discrimination in the EU. It has always made clear that discrimination against LGBTI people has no place in the European Union. All EU Member States and state authorities alike, without exception, must respect EU values and fundamental rights. As indicated by the honourable Members, the Court of Justice of the EU has recently clarified the interpretation of the Equal Treatment Directive with regard to public declarations expressing a discriminatory opinion or intention about the potential recruitment of LGBTI persons. The Court referred to several factors which have to be taken into consideration in assessing whether such declarations are covered by the directive. The Court pointed out that these issues are of a factual nature.  The declarations issued by Polish regional or municipal councils vary in their nature. Some seem mainly to focus on education or so—called ideology, whereas others also refer to the selection of employees, albeit in a rather vague way. The Commission has not yet received any specific complaint by any person alleging violation of his or her rights derived from EU law following the adoption of the above declarations. However, the Commission is thoroughly examining the situation in the light of the prohibition of discrimination enshrined in the EU acquis. It is assessing the precise purpose, scope and effects of the declarations at issue in view of a possible violation of EU law. Should there be a violation, the Commission, as guardian of the EU Treaties, will make use of its powers.  The Commission has already, on several occasions, encouraged the Polish authorities to revoke discriminatory resolutions, charters and similar statements. It has reminded the Polish authorities of the importance of promoting respect for fundamental rights and freedoms, social inclusion, gender equality and combating discrimination.  We stand ready to support the Polish authorities in combating discrimination, including on the basis of sexual orientation. The Commission – my colleague Helena Dalli – will present an LGBTI equality strategy in November this year. Within this framework, the Commission will continue to provide appropriate funding to foster a conducive and sustainable environment for LGBTI civil-society organisations. In addition, the Commission will maintain and encourage a structured and open dialogue and consultation with civil society. EU values and fundamental rights must be respected by Member States and state authorities alike. Discrimination against LGBTI people has no place in the EU and the Commission will continue to fight against all kinds of discrimination.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, Commissioner, Commissioner Jourov, I would like to thank the Commissioner for her excellent work and for her excellent work. Thank you for the detailed words just now. The Polish government has spent the last few months in pledurising hatred and exclusion against LGBTI people. What a shame! Especially in times of crisis, it is necessary to keep society together and not to promote division. The salami tactics of the PIS government are curtailing more and more people in their rights: first LGTBI people and now also women, who already receive little real formal protection from violence and are even more at risk, by massive restrictions on their rights by the government. As the European Union, we must ensure that our fundamental values are respected and that all people – indeed all people – can lead a self-determined, free life without fear. States that do not comply can no longer receive EU money, and only a rule of law mechanism in the next Multiannual Financial Framework can guarantee this.

name: Andrzej HALICKI
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Madam Vice-President of the Commission, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schwa Today I am standing before the High Chamber as a representative of the Group of the European People's Party, but also – and perhaps above all – as a Polish parliamentarian, because it is my duty to say and respond to this report in the name of truth, in the name of confronting what is written in the report with reality. Who can do this more objectively than the one who lives in this country?  Of course, I would like this report not to be. I would like and hope that there will come a time when Polish society will choose power so well that it will not put itself above the law. Because this report is an indictment of a power that puts itself above the law, above the constitution, and also harasses those who think differently. And we'll probably hear these screams or spells here sometimes, that it's ideology, that it's intentions. No, this report is a set of facts and a description of events. Very balanced.  There is no agreement that the authorities discriminate against anyone in any European country. If that is the case, then we must say in this House that this cannot be the case. There is no consensus that the authorities are bullish on the courts and want to be courts in the name of their own interests. There is no agreement to threaten the independence of the media simply because someone's opinion of power does not like it. There is also no consent to hate speech, and if words of aggression come from the mouths of top-level politicians, then you have to react, you have to react strongly. Therefore, we will not rest in Poland – it is our task, Polish society. But I would like to say, on behalf of the ppe group as a whole, that this report must be adopted, because it is simply – unfortunately – true.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the The report on Poland: In December 2017, three years ago, the Commission launched the Article 7 procedure – since then, a standstill in the Council and thus, intentionally or unintentionally, further encouragement to continue the anti-democratic path.  The last weeks and months have once again clearly shown that democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights do not matter to the PiS government. There has long been no question of independent justice. Media and more and more organizations come under the control of PiS. Instead of a clear fight against violence against women, an announced withdrawal from the Istanbul Convention. We are witnessing massive discrimination and incitement against people on the basis of their sexual orientation and identity and explicit support for so-called LGBTI-free zones. If the Member States continue to watch in the Council, the EU will lose its credibility as a continent of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. The Member States must finally do something. Stop becoming a henchman of Orban, PiS and Co. Finally, position yourself clearly. Anchor a binding and efficient rule of law mechanism in the forthcoming budget. Now you have the chance to secure our values for all the people of Europe. Do not let this opportunity pass.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, it is now almost three years since the Commission has launched the Article 7 procedure against Poland and we are still going round in circles, as has also been highlighted by Mr López Aguilar. And since then we see Poland crossing red line after red line, and the strategy of the Member States is appeasement. But in the meantime, the situation has got worse, obviously. We see LGBTI-free zones in Poland, in Europe, the return of witch hunts in Europe – something I thought I would never see. Today several NGOs have lodged a legal complaint at the Commission regarding the LGBTI-free zones, and judges in other EU Member States are now refusing to cooperate with judges in Poland and to use the European Arrest Warrant. Such civic action is very welcome, but why are the Commission and the Council not doing their job on this? Because frankly, Madam Commissioner, after three years I don’t want to hear the word ‘dialogue’ anymore. We’ve been in dialogue with Mr Orbán for 10 years and look at where we are now. It is impunity: dialogue equals impunity by now. It is time for action. I understand that Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner Reynders are ready to take action and to pursue the two pending procedures which are in court, but you’re being blocked by Ms von der Leyen. Ms von der Leyen is going to address this Chamber on Wednesday, and I’m sure she’s going to speak very moving words on the rule of law. But Ms von der Leyen, it’s time to act, it’s time to deliver, and I do not want to hear her say anymore that nobody is perfect –because impunity is encouraging other governments inside and outside Europe. How can we have moral authority, as Ms Sippel said, when we are giving support to the people in Belarus, when we are too chicken to tackle the governments of Poland and the governments of Hungary, and many others. It’s time to act. Now!

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the interim report by the European Parliament, entirely dependent on Poland, is aimed only at putting the nations out of line, confirming the uniformity of nations that Mrs von der Leyen wishes to impose. The initiation of the Article 7 procedure against Poland is a humiliation, an unacceptable infringement of its sovereignty. The legal argument is also fragile in several respects. One example among many: the report highlights the bias of the media in Poland. But, objectively, in which country in the world would the media be impartial? Let's be careful. Moreover, the stigmatization of LGBT people after the return to power of the conservative Law and Justice party in 2015 remains to be supported. The arrest of militants is not a generality. At present, in the eyes of the world, Brussels gives the image of a weak Europe in the face of Erdogan's bellicose attitude in the eastern Mediterranean , which even paid itself the luxury of directly threatening the French frigate Courbet on 30 August last - but which asserts with unheard of aplomb that the situation in Poland will have a negative impact on the situation of the Member States. The courage of the European Union would require not an authority over Poland, but a determination to stop all funding for Turkey, which is in violation of Greek maritime areas and illegally occupies northern Syria.

name: Terry REINTKE
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, when we look at the situation in Poland and when we look at the findings of this report, we can clearly state that this is not just a systematic breach of the rule of law anymore, but this is a fully fledged rule of law crisis, in the middle, in the heart, of the European Union.  If you think that I’m exaggerating the situation, or that I’m overstating something, I would like to give you one number, and maybe you are going to rethink that judgment. Currently 10% of all Polish judges, one in ten – in some districts, every single judge – is under urgent threat of being targeted with disciplinary measures.  What was their crime? They think that defending the rule of law and defending the independence of the judiciary is something that you can actually say out loud.  This is an unprecedented attack on EU values and the very foundation of the European Union, and probably not one, not two, and maybe not even five, Court of Justice of the Eureopan Union rulings are going to be enough when the ruling party is trying to take political control of the judiciary.  We have to stand not only with the judges in Poland, but we have to stand with the EU citizens that are demanding access to justice in Poland.  As the co-chair of the LGBTI Intergroup, I can tell you that every week, every single week, we receive more messages of worry and sometimes, I must say, despair from the LGBTI community in Poland.  Every week there are new attacks, every week there are new lies spread, there is new anti-LGBTI propaganda, and I don’t know what to tell them anymore, Madam Commissioner, because they all ask the same question: when is the European Union finally going to act? The silence of the Commission over this summer has been screaming into the faces of all of those people whose rights are under attack right now. And I urge you: do something, start an infringement procedure against LGBTI-free zones in Poland now, Madam Commissioner. Lastly, and I hope, especially, that Mr Duda is watching but also to our colleagues from the Polish ruling party here in this Chamber: look at me, look at Marc, look at Malin, look at Maria. We are not an ideology. We are human beings. We are made out of flesh and blood. We want to have exactly the same fundamental human rights like everyone else. And I know that deep inside of you, you actually know that, so stop using us and the LGBTI community in Poland for your disgusting political agenda.

name: Patryk JAKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. –Mr President, above all I need to underline that there are no LGBT-free zones in Poland. I say to Ms Reintke: there is only a left-wing activist who creates displays and illegal signs and sends you a picture and you believe it. So once again I call on you to maintain the seriousness of your office. But to get to the point: thank you very much for providing us, at last, with a definition of the rule of law. In your interpretation, the rule of law in Poland is being violated by, firstly, the adoption of the anti-terrorist law – even if you know there are similar laws in the other Member States. Secondly, by the appointment of the judges – which is done in the same way as in Spain. You know, in Poland the judicial council is appointed by parliament, like in Spain, by the same majority as in Spain, and you say: ‘In Spain everything is good but in Poland you harm the rule of law’. And this is equal treatment? Then in your definition, the existence of just one big Conservative television channel harms the rule of law. And merely holding a debate on abortion – not approving anything, only having a debate – harms the rule of law, in your definition. And the adoption of a solution in civil law to defend the good name of Poland, which is a fundamental right of every citizen and every country, you say that this is still harming the rule of law. Then the prohibition of the political activities of judges, which is a fundamental thing for the independence of judges – and we have this in the Constitution, by the way – in your opinion this is against the rule of law. The same thing when we don’t provide leftist organisations with more money out of public funds. And finally, the adoption of Regional Family Rights Law. Yes, it is true: in your interpretation, defending family law is harming the rule of law. So to conclude: everything which is not leftist is harming the rule of law in your interpretation. That’s why I need to ask you something: did you even understand what the rule of law is? Do you know what democracy is? The fundamental thing about democracy and European values is freedom of speech, freedom of expression, and the right to create a political group, a Christian political group, a Conservative political group, like Robert Schuman did. I need to tell you something: we in Poland know this kind of ideology. In the past, the Communists used the language of ‘I tell you...’. The Communists called censorship ‘the principles of freedom’: the restriction of religious practice, the freedom of conscience. And today you call a left-wing bandit beating a man a child who has been arrested for his beliefs, and supporting the traditional family you call an ‘attack on tolerance’. I tell you something, and I want to underline something: I am not surprised that the new monument in Germany of Lenin – a murderer, a tyrant – does not bother you. But the maintenance of family values in Poland does. Shame on you, shame on you!

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: , on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I say to Mr Jaki: shame on you for trying to trample on my rights. I stand here proud, in solidarity with my LGBTI colleagues in Poland. Today, LGBTI people in Poland are under attack in the streets and in the courts, as our colleagues making the Atlas of Hate have shown. I encourage you all to visit it on the web. I think it is important to recognise that the rule of law, democracy and respect for fundamental rights go together. You cannot take away one and keep ‘a little bit of this and a little bit of that’. So we can see that the lack of independence for the courts, the lack of media freedom and pluralism, the attacks on women’s rights highlighted here in the Chamber and the attacks on the LGBTI community go together. We will not let this go on. We will not let the bullying go on. This House will stand up for the rule of law, democracy and fundamental rights, and we will have an EU budget that doesn’t give money to those Member States like Poland that cannot respect fundamental rights and democracy and the rule of law.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Acerra, in the province of Naples, on the night between Friday and Saturday, a girl died after being rammed by her brother on a scooter, who did not accept his relationship with a trans boy. Today in Europe we are still light years away from eradicating this culture of hatred and discrimination, which takes too many innocent victims every year.  The time has come to do much more against homophobia, especially when it is the public authorities that act as megaphones, as is the case in Poland, where a third of the national territory has decided to identify people belonging to the LGBT community as threats to Polish culture and identity. LGBT-free zones are a real attack on European values and must be treated as such.  I therefore repeat the request for concrete action from the Commission, for infringement proceedings to be opened against Poland and for any funding directly or indirectly benefiting local authorities which have declared themselves LGBT-free zones to be blocked.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: – Mr President, I want to talk about the attempt to intimidate judges in Poland. I want to tell the judges that we will never turn our backs on what is happening, that justice matters more than electoral majorities. But today I need to talk about the ethos of Europe, that we are all different and yet all equal. That a German, a Maltese, a Pole and a Latvian national could walk down the street in a village in Poland and expect the same rights and the same level of protection. That any Jew or Catholic, atheist or devout of any religion could do the same. That we could all feel safe in every little town across our Europe. That straight, gay, lesbian, bi, trans or non-binary, you are free to live your life without fear, without recrimination, without arrest, because that is what our Europe is, and that’s why we remain the beacon of hope in a world that is under threat, because while we may all be different we are all equal.  Having LGBT-free zones means having Europe-free zones and if there is one corner of this Union where Europeans are not welcome, then that is one corner too many. So to those people who are feeling desperate, to those parents who are terrified for their children’s safety, to those young people who expect us to keep our promise to them that they can live their lives freely: your family matters, too. Yours is not an invasive ideology, yours is a Polish ideology, a European ideology.  So in conclusion, we have your back: Europe stands with you because we understand that while we are all different, we are all equal.  (Applause)

name: Sylwia SPUREK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I apologize to our friends and friends LGTB+! I am sorry that the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Council cannot defend your rights. We do not create a community in which everyone and everyone is equal, feels safe regardless of gender or sexual orientation.  Poland has not respected the human rights of LGBT+ people for years. No partnerships, not even to mention marriage equality, no modern right to gender reconciliation, no anti-discrimination education. LGBT+ people are not protected from hate speech and hate crimes. Now there is the government's hatred of LGBT+ people, police brutality and "LGBT+ free zones."  Thirty-three months ago, the Article 7 procedure was triggered Polish the Commission. Over the last three years, we have seen successive areas of the Polish being violated by the government. Where is the European Commission? How long will it monitor, appeal and recommend? Where is the mechanism binding the rule of law to EU funds? When will governments in Poland and Hungary stop feeling unpunished?  Madam Vice-President, what else needs to happen for the Commission to work effectively?

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Polish Government, do not be afraid of your own fellow citizens, of their diversity, of their aspiration for freedom, equality and life. Ladies and gentlemen of the European Commission, Madam Vice-President, do not be afraid to push infringement procedures, impose fines, cut subsidies. We cannot say yes to European funds but no to values. Don't be afraid to promote and protect the European way of life. Ladies and gentlemen, do not be afraid to let all European citizens know that we are here, that here in the European Parliament, respect for the values of the European Union is an inexhaustible horizon. We must say this to all our fellow citizens: do not be afraid to claim your fundamental rights! We say this to these LGBT activists so abused by the Polish police, to those who fight, but also to those who hide: do not be afraid to be who you are, do not be afraid to live free, do not be afraid to live! We tell you this: don't be afraid!

name: Maximilian KRAH
text: – Mr President, what we see again is an attack on Poland, not because of the violation of the European Treaties, but we see the usual attacks on conservative politics by those who are on the left side of the political spectrum. We have these biased reports. It was the Sargentini report on Hungary, it is now the López Aguilar report on Poland. That is not fair, but it wants to implement leftist politics in Poland against the will of the people. The Polish people have elected a conservative majority to get conservative politics. The policy on justice and on judges’ appointments becomes now the European standard in Poland.  A country that does not have European standard is Germany, where the President of the Constitutional Court was a member of parliament and became a directly appointed judge and then president. And if you look at family policy – and I have read the charter of the rights of family in Poland – I can only applaud the Polish people to have a policy which is focused on families with daddy, mummy and children, and not on different minorities.  Opposing the gender theory does not mean to suppress gay and LGBTI people, it just means that we don’t want those theories taught in schools and universities and made the principle of politics. Poland and Hungary have decided to follow a conservative line, which is a sovereign decision of the people, and so do people have the right to follow that policy, and it is not an oppression of the treaties. I can only address my Polish friends: follow your way, you are right.

name: Gwendoline DELBOS-CORFIELD
text: Mr President, by undermining the declines in rights and freedoms over the past decade, by letting it be said that our values can be negotiated, we have created our own monsters within the European Union. We have allowed official areas of territory to develop in the European Union where LGBTI people are not accepted in a public way. However, the foundations of the rule of law, our imprescriptible rights, our freedoms are not negotiable. On the contrary, they are universal and intangible, and there can be no definition according to the state in which one lives. These are rights written in our texts and charters, inherited from our common stories of atrocities and heroic struggles. When the Polish government wants to withdraw from the Istanbul Convention because it claims that it contains harmful ideological elements or when it wants to further restrict the right to abortion, it is the rights of women, universal, intangible and imprescriptible, that are under attack! When this same government claims that there is a supposed LGBTI ideology, it is still the human rights of all, intangible, universal and imprescriptible, that are trampled! When the independence of the judiciary, the pluralism of the media, the rights of the opposition are threatened in a state, it is again the basic rules of law that are not accepted. And when the Commission refuses to carry out infringement proceedings against these guilty States, because it has supposed legal doubts, we can ask ourselves: do the people who, at the highest level of the institutions, make the legal interpretation really want to protect all these rights?

name: Pernando BARRENA ARZA
text: – Mr President, the Polish Government does not appear to have been affected by the European Union activating its so-called 'nuclear option' in Article 7 for the first time in history. And this is because it has been raised, in our view, in a complex way, in this case, and while, in addition, other flagrant situations are avoided, such as, at the time, that of violence in France against yellow vests or, in Spain, that of police repression in Catalonia and the Basque Country.  We believe that the Council and the Commission still do not live up to it when it comes to protecting Polish citizens from continued violations of their fundamental rights. We want them to stop reinterpreting the principle of the rule of law restrictively and to be just as harsh when attacks on the rights of women or LGTBI persons occur, for example. The latter are being subjected to increasing harassment and we find it unacceptable for Poland's own president to publicly stand up against them.  Something must be done and it must be done now, and that is why we call on the Council to declare a serious and persistent violation of Article 2 and to issue recommendations, and to the Commission to use all the instruments at its disposal to address the situation in the country.

name: Vladimír BILČÍK
text: – Mr President, this is a very emotional debate but the core issue is that Polish justice is European justice, and the safety, dignity and freedom of all citizens in Poland – regardless of their gender and sexual orientation – is also about essential respect for the rights of all Europeans. Fight for a fairer Poland is our fight for fair Europe. Freedom of media are inseparable from democracy and rule of law. Independent public broadcasters help democracy thrive. On the other hand, state media network as a tool of those in power is a disservice to Polish citizens and citizens everywhere. Misusing the media through political power is a departure from democratic ideals we share in this House, no matter which Member State we come from. Difficult discussion about the quality of justice in Poland is a stark reminder that we are in dire need of a more robust approach to the protection of rule-of-law issues in Europe. This must be a joint priority for the Council, Commission and European Parliament. Europe must pay equal attention to rule-of-law issues across all Member States in order to prevent further loss of justice from all Europeans. Polish justice deserves our attention for the sake of Europe.

name: Marek Paweł BALT
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Poland is a country I love, but decisions have been made that I absolutely cannot be indifferent to. In 2016, 40,000 uniformed officers who worked for the Polish were stripped of their pensions overnight. Their service until 1989 was declared non-existe, and reduced after 1989. These people have been trying for many years to assert their rights, but their right to a court is limited. They are mainly elderly people, often ailed, focused on living day by day on a level that respects human dignity. €160 is the monthly amount of the pension that has been granted to them for life. A thousand people have already died without justice, 61 have committed suicide or died as a result of a nervous breakdown.  By introducing Polish a repressive law, the government has violated, among other things, the principle of citizens' trust in the state and the law they legied, the principle of non-retroactivity, and, moreover, violated the right to social security after reaching retirement age, thereby violating the Polish Constitution and the European Convention for the Protection of Human Rights. This is unacceptable. Someone cannot be punished for actions he did not commit without trial, especially since the officers in question were positively verified and, after the transformation, served in a free, independent, democratic Poland. The officials have already asked the European Parliament for help once, there was an official hearing on this issue two years ago, but nothing has been done for them. Please do not be indifferent again.

name: Alice KUHNKE
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr The absolute majority of us are well aware that developments in Poland have been going in the wrong direction for a long time. The absolute majority of us are well aware that what is going on is wrong and dangerous. However, not enough of us are prepared to move from words to deeds. What are we if we do not act vigorously when the rights of women and LGBTQ people are curtailed, and when the independence of the judiciary and the media is undermined? It is clear that the EU Heads of Government are not doing enough. Then it is up to us elected parliamentarians to put hard. Let us use that opportunity that the fight over money provides. Krona for Crown should be set against the requirement to respect eu values.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: – Mr President, the Polish Government is one of the best examples of europe's authoritarian drift, one of the main exponents of the reactionary international that uses sexual and reproductive rights and the body of women as a battleground. An authoritarianism that we also see, and which has been baited, with the LGTBI collective, and we see it in gay-free zones, a totally unacceptable and homophobic policy. It attacks anyone who defies his policies, as has happened to polish sociologist Pankowski, who has received threats for positioning himself against homophobic policies and for his anti-racist and anti-progressive work in Poland.  And while all this happens, the European Union continues to accept it, it continues to accept far-right blackmail. A clear example is to have accepted the xenophobic policy of the Polish Government, clearing the possibility of establishing a fair quota system with refugees and migrants in the new migration pact. It's a disgrace. We cannot continue to look the other way, with what is happening, with the authoritarian drift we are seeing in Europe.

name: Maria WALSH
text: – Mr President, Madam Vice-President, colleagues, fellow LGBTQI community members, and our allies, both in the Chamber and indeed working in the institutions, today the entire European Union is at risk. The European project hangs in the balance. This is about more than just the terrible LGBTQI rights violations in Poland. This is about who we are, and it is about what our European Union stands for.  Do we not value freedom, equality and the rule of law above all else? Was the European Union not founded to protect our citizens’ rights against discrimination? The desire to protect our people – all our people, regardless of their sexuality or gender identity – is why we stand here today. And we do not discriminate when it comes to protecting the fundamental rights of any of our European citizens.  If we do not take decisive action against a government that is punishing our people for simply existing, then what are we here for? What are we here for? The European Commission and the European Council have to take stronger action against the Polish Government, not only to protect the Polish LGBTQI community members, but also to protect our fundamental values and protect our European Union.

name: Łukasz KOHUT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by I will speak in Polish and Silesian a bit.  After ours, in Ślonsk it is godo: niy mo wom gańba, Mr What? Are you not ashamed? For the past five years, you have been violating fundamental European principles in Poland: the rule of law, human rights and civil liberties. You have brought the Constitutional Court into the role of puppet, you have made a propaganda tube out of the public media, you are cooking hell for women. You made Polish a ridiculous cabaret, a laughing stock on the international stage. You brought arrogance, shoe and xenophobia to the altars. You deny rights to all who do not want your backwater vision of Polish, a country where the alliance of the throne and the altar rules. Isn't it a shame when you offend judges, or are you not ashamed when more LGBT people decide to emigrate?  You do not want to recognize the Silesian ethnic minority, you are afraid of the Silesian language, you deliberately hide the black cards of history, including the Upper Silesian tragedy. You are scaring people that Poland will lose European funds. Don't scare, this money can bypass your lawlessness and go straight to local government. Real good change is possible, it is the PiS government that must be punished for its actions, not the citizens.  I will tell you at the end: whatever you do, how far you will go in the policy of leaving the Union, Silesia will stay in Europe – here is our place. And friends from Europe please: don't let us walk along. Poland is not PiS.

name: Grace O'SULLIVAN
text: – Mr President, it’s shocking that in this year, 2020, we have a situation in Poland with some of the towns declaring themselves LGBTI—free zones. This is a patent violation of the most basic human rights. I speak as a member of the European Parliament’s LGBTI Intergroup, but also as a citizen of a traditionally Catholic country with a large – and, can I say, welcome – Polish community. Ireland also happens to be the first country in the world to have introduced marriage equality for same sex couples through a popular vote. LGBTI—free zones are an abhorrent infringement of people’s rights to dignity and equality, and I wholeheartedly support calls for Parliamentary, Commission-led and international condemnation and action on this distressing issue.

name: Balázs HIDVÉGHI
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. In recent years, it has become common practice for eu institutions to use the rule of law as a political weapon and a stick against some Member States, without any objectivity. Poland and Hungary have been prosecuted for years for trampling on the principles of due process and prosecution, which is about ideological issues, serves only political purposes and thus does not itself meet the requirements of the rule of law. The rule of law cannot be held to account by applying different standards to Member States by adopting accusation reports instead of dialogue, subjecting them to years of non-coastal proceedings. The reality is that where a government with a characterful right-wing politics is formed, sooner or later the allegations of the rule of law will emerge. This is the case with Hungary and Poland, but we have seen this recently in slovenia and bulgaria. At the same time, the Socialists and liberals, your comrades, are brazenly silent in blatant cases that violate the rule of law, such as the death of The Slovak Jozef Chovanec here in Belgium following a police operation that is not being investigated. Or, for example, when the Hungarian left launches an openly anti-Semitic politician in an interim parliamentary election in Hungary at the beginning of October. When we ask you about this, there is no rule of law problem, and there are no answers. What is this, ladies and gentlemen, if not a double standard? Thank you very much!

name: Tilly METZ
text: Mr President, in December 2019, I spoke proudly of my same-sex marriage, full of hope for an inclusive Europe, despite the unacceptable blocking of the Equal Treatment Directive since 2008. Shame on the Council. Today, I don't know if I can still set foot in Poland, with a near-public spread of intolerance and violence against the LGBTI community. Stop hate, stop discrimination under the pretext of religion or freedom of expression! The European Court of Justice recently reaffirmed this in April: freedom of expression is not absolute and can be limited to protect the rights of others. It is not a question of making the Union a police of thought or speech, but a guardian of fundamental rights and the rule of law. In this way, we call on the Council and the Commission to intervene to defend the values on which our community is founded.

name: Rasmus ANDRESEN
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the "They are trying to convince you that they are human beings. But that's just ideology.' With these words, Polish President Duda has spread hatred against LGBTI people during the election campaign. We Greens believe that no president in the world has the right to rush against minorities. Most of us cannot imagine what this incitement must be for young Polish LGBTI people. What it's like to be rejected by your own family, or what fear parents are when their children are gay. What it's like to be beaten up just because you walk through the street with your partner. Since the Polish election campaign, the situation for LGBTI people in Poland has deteriorated dramatically, and it is therefore important to show solidarity. We are doing this here in the European Parliament: we stand up for the rights of LGBTI people throughout Europe, and we must continue to do so. We should be more specific, we should fight to ensure that NGOs are better supported and that these people get a loud voice.

name: Hermann TERTSCH
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this persecution of Poland is all right. It is already enough of the persecution of Hungary and any free European nation that dares to challenge all the ideological mantras of this progressive consensus. This is not a debate on the rule of law. This, what it is, is the usual thing: a lynching and an attempt at public humiliation on a Parliament, a sovereign country that refuses to be pushed into that social democratic consensus that is to be imposed from here. That's what it's all about. And you, everyone, know that.  I am very concerned that this House is not aware that this report offends the sovereign Polish nation and exercises infinite hypocrisy, since its rapporteur is a member of a party that today trampls obscenely and has completely destroyed the division of powers in Spain, in alliance with the communists. With a government that has a attorney general appointed by them to destroy that division, and formerly socialist minister of justice. Where we have that socialist prosecutor who destroys the separation and we have judges threatened by Vice President Pablo Iglesias. That is what we have in Spain, in the country where this gentleman's party rules, which is now trying to threaten Poland.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, thank you very much for this very important debate about a very serious issue which was not only about the situation in Poland, but also I understood that this was a wider context in the debate about the rule of law situation in the EU.  Let me start with with a recollection of how we felt about the rule of law and values some years ago, maybe 10 years ago. We used to speak about the independent judges and about the freedom of speech and a vibrant civil society, free and fair elections. It was with a very relaxed voice, as if we had created some kind of perpetuum mobile for values in the EU. Now we see that we have to deploy all possible powers and measures to renew the importance of the values like rule of law, fundamental rights and democracy to the European Union, because these are the values the EU was thus founded on.  And speaking about measures, I indeed described what we do in the field of infringement procedures. We can only use them when there is a clear violation of EU law. It might sound legalistic. It is. It is a legal approach, as Ms Delbos-Corfield mentioned, but we, the Commission, are not activists.  We can only start infringement procedures when we have a very solid legal ground, and believe me, I want to win the cases. We cannot afford to lose the cases which relate to rule of law issues. It’s too important, and we need also to work on the credibility of the EU, and losing the cases would not be a good thing. That’s why I wanted to attract your attention also to the previous cases where they were all successful. And important cases relating to rule of law. Article 7: we obviously see that there was a lack of imagination in those who created the Lisbon Treaty, who foresaw the Article 7 as a functional measure. We see now that it’s toothless. We have lengthy procedures, we have the debate about Hungary and Poland, and it’s not only Hungary supporting Poland and vice versa. There are other Member States who are supporting States where we see obvious breach of the basic principle of the rule of law.  So we have to deploy further measures. Obviously, we have to accelerate more and more powers and to be also innovative in how to support the rule of law in the Member States. That’s why we proposed the rule of law conditionality, the linkage between the rule of law principle and the budget.  You know that there was a very difficult debate on the night of 21 June when the Council was adopting the new budget, and the talks will continue. I do believe that we need such an instrument. I sometimes say in a rather cynical way that whoever doesn’t understand the values usually understands the money. Let’s use this instrument. We need it. And also because the taxpayers of many Member States are fed up with funding projects in the countries where fundamental rights are violated. And here I come also to the issue of the breach of the rights of the LGBTI people. Where we are now with the budget is a very dangerous situation. The bigger the money, the lower the trust. I think that this is devastating. We need to promote the idea of linking the EU taxpayers’ money with the basic principles of the EU.  The second measure which we want to use is also a response to the criticism which I heard from this side of Parliament that that is double or triple standards, different treatments, that we are only focusing on Poland and Hungary. It was never my goal. I always wanted to make a very objective and fair comparison of the situation of the rule of law in the Member States and it cannot be done by comparing two laws or two articles in two different laws in Germany and Poland or in Hungary and Spain. We have to look at the broader picture in all the Member States. That’s why we are now finishing the work on the rule of law report where we will focus not only on the situation of the judiciary but also on media and on the anti-corruption fight, because we believe that these are interconnected features and factors and we should be able to make an objective assessment.  The way of assessing is very transparent. Also the authorities in Poland and all the other Member States had a possibility to comment on the findings and we will soon make the reports public and make further comments. Indeed, it was also said here, we need a better definition of what we mean by the rule of law. We will do that. We will always make better and better explanations because we also simply have to explain on a continuous basis to the citizens of the EU why we need the rule of law principle in place, why we need an independent judge. There is a lack of awareness of how important the principle is for every single citizen.  So I believe that these two new instruments will help to increase our ability. Now it will be a quote in many of your speeches to do ‘something;. We need to do something more.  My objective is also – and it is the reaction of Sophia in ‘t Veld – that there has been enough dialogue. My objective is to continue the dialogue because Poland is an EU Member State, and I really want to invite Poland back to Europe where we esteem and respect values. Sorry I am long. On the LGBTI issue, I am in permanent contact with the Polish Ombudsman. We have strengthened the competences of equality bodies which are available for LGBTI people. We need to be clearer that the financial resources of the EU will not be paid in case there is such a violation of the fundamental rights of people. And it was a good thing that we stopped the funding of the six projects because there was no clarification of what’s happening there.  I was happy to see also the peer pressure of other municipalities which didn’t want to cooperate, because what we see in some of the municipalities is a big worry that the LGBTI people are under big threat. Moreover, when we hear the aggressive rhetoric against LGBTI people from the political circles, it is a kind of authorisation to do the same thing for the whole society. I find this intolerable. The Commission will continue working on this issue. You said that you don’t want to hear anything about monitoring and analysing. Well we are now analysing how to react to the declarations elaborated by the municipalities because the legal issue is that they are not laws or sub-laws which could be addressed by the infringement procedure, but we are trying to find a way. And from this place I would like to send a lot of encouragement to LGBTI people because Europe is standing behind them.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you for your generosity in granting me one last minute simply to thank you for the livelyness of this debate. I appreciate all the interventions and appreciate, of course, those with which I have shared principles. But I have also appreciated those which have opposed the contents of this report head-on.  I would like to tell you that this would not be the tenth resolution on Poland if it were to prosecute a law — whether on the Constitutional Court, on the Judicial Council or on minority rights — but what is prosecuted is its abrupt accumulation over time and without concession to any minority. Because this is the point: it has never been true that the rule of law and democracy in Europe are simply the claim of national sovereignty and the law of the majority. On the contrary: it is shared sovereignty over the protection of the right to dissent, the opposition, and the protection of minorities, as expressed here; minorities who have opposed this report.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: A motion for a resolution has been tabled in accordance with Rule 136(5) of the Rules of Procedure*. The joint debate is closed. The vote on the amendments to the report will take place on Wednesday, 16 September 2020, and the final vote will take place on Thursday, 17 September 2020.

name: Joachim Stanisław BRUDZIŃSKI
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Mr Agilar's report does not represent an adequate level of substance. It is impossible not to notice that Poland is trying to teach democracy to politicians from a country where new ideologies are beginning to resemble totalitarianism. Children have lessons in schools with descriptions of masturbation and are encouraged to "denunciate their parents if they commit homophobic crimes." It already was. In the totalitarian USSR, in which Pawka Morozov became a hero, giving his parents Stalin's orphans only because they had different views than communist power. It was in Spain that parliament recently voted to murder people, or euthanasia, which had already been applied to the oldest coronovirus patients, whom doctors had selected for treatment, but for care home workers. This begs the association with another totalitarianism – german death camps from World War II, where those who could no longer work ended up in the death chambers. People from such countries try to instruct Poland. They argue that we lack the rule of law, although the ruling party recently confirmed its mandate in democratic elections, winning an independent majority for the second time in a row.  I ask the politicians attacking Poland: where were you when, under the rule of our opponents, the special services entered the "Wprost" editorial office? Why were you silent when the judges of the Constitutional Tribunal were elected, even though the predecessors' term of office was not over? You are hypocrites.

name: Elżbieta KRUK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The debates on the rule of law in Poland and Hungary show that many members of this House believe in anything and do not think for themselves. The truth is that the allegations against the Polish not only do not represent the actual state of affairs, but the opposite of the actual state of affairs. Poland is accused of introducing solutions into the justice system that already exist in many EU Member States.  Secondly, Poland is accused of intolerance when statistics show that violence against national minorities resulting from anti-Semitism, Islamophobia or xenophobia is on the rise in Western European countries. In Germany, for example, there are up to 5 racially motivated attacks per day. Where are the equal standards? Where to respect EU law? After all, the EU does not have competence in this area.  We invite you to Polish. You'll be surprised. You will see a safe and tolerant country. Poles are an open nation, which is due to our history, culture and traditions. For centuries, national minorities from other countries, such as Jews from Spain, have found refuge in Poland. Just as cars do not burn in Poland today, piles have never burned here. If you do not fear different views and freedom of expression, respect the right of peoples to their own traditions and value the values of our civilization – then you will see the truth about Poland.

name: Beata MAZUREK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Do Members of the European Parliament, who are once again attacking Poland for alleged 'violations of the rule of law', know the basic facts and are aware of the judicial reform being carried out, or are they only succumbing to the propaganda of the political opposition in Poland?  Mr Aguilar, whose report we are debating, has effectively erased the fact that in Spain the Council for the Judiciary is elected in the same way as in Poland, that is, through parliament, but it is in Poland that the rule of law is being violated and in Spain it is not.  He also forgot about the Dantej scenes in his country, where the police brutally pacified demonstrations in Catalonia without sparing women and the elderly. How does this have to do with the right to organize assemblies and peacefully manifest their views? Similar situations have been observed in France during protests by workers and trade unions. In Poland, for five years, since Law and Justice was in power, opposition demonstrations have been protected, not dispersed by the police. That is why allegations of breaking the law are an obvious lie.  As an example of violations of the rule of law in Poland, which you have raised on the banners of the fight against the Polish government, there are so-called LGBT-free zones. This is the ordinary lie of one of the left-wing activists who invented this action in order to discredit the good Polish on the international stage. We strongly oppose the vilification of the good name of Polish.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on – the oral question to the Council on the strategic approach to medicinal products in the environment by Cristian-Silviu Buoi, Günther Sidl, Jan Huitema, Michele Rivasi, Simona Baldassarre, Joanna Kopcisska and Kateina Koneenon, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000040/2020 - B9-0015/20) and – the oral question to the Commission on the strategic approach to medicinal products in the environment of Cristian-Silviu Buoi, Günther Sidl, Jan Huitema, Michele Rivasi, Simona Baldassarre, Joanna Kopcisska and Katesina Koneenon on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (O-000041/2020 - B9-0015/20).

name: Günther SIDL
text: Author. Mr President, representatives of the Council and the Commission. I should like to begin by apologising to my colleague, Mr Buoi, who cannot be here today, and I should therefore like to put this question to the Council and the Commission on behalf of the Committee on the Environment. On 11 March 2019, the Commission adopted its Communication entitled 'The European Union's strategic approach to medicinal products in the environment'. Article 8c of the Priority Substances Directive provides that the present strategic approach should, where appropriate, be followed by proposals for measures to be taken at Union and/or Member State level to address the possible environmental impact of pharmaceutical substances, thereby reducing discharges, emissions and losses of these substances into water, taking into account the needs of public health and the cost-effectiveness of the proposed measures. The Communication identifies six areas of action and several specific activities related to possible measures: increased education and promotion of prudent use of medicinal products, support for the development of medicines that are less harmful to the environment, and promotion of more environmentally friendly production, improvement of environmental impact assessment and its review, reduction of waste and improvement of waste management, evaluation of environmental monitoring and closing other knowledge gaps.  I would therefore like to turn to the questions, firstly on the Council: in its conclusions of June 2019, the Council calls on the Commission to assess and identify the joint measures, including initiatives, to reduce the environmental impact of medicines and to combat the development of resistance to antimicrobial agents and, in this respect, to strengthen the introduction to the health sector. Hence the two questions: what is the Council's position on the strategic approach and the measures set out by the Commission? Secondly, what legislative and non-legislative measures does the Council intend to support in order to reduce the risk of medicines in the environment?  The second question to the Commission is that there is sufficient evidence that rapid action should be taken to reduce the risk of medicinal products in the environment. The two questions: what legislative and non-legislative measures does the Commission intend to take to reduce the risk of medicines in the environment?  Secondly, what is the timetable for these measures?

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Thank you very much, Mr President, ladies and for inquiries. I would now like to give the floor to the representative of the German Presidency and the Council, Mr Michael Roth, and also to tell him that I am glad for the House that you were already there during the debate on the rule of law mechanism and Poland, because this is a very important debate for Parliament, also in the light of the decisions on the multiannual financial framework.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, honourable Members, I sometimes take the right to be here if you have not invited me decisively. However, I am particularly honoured to be able to convey the Council's position on this important issue, honourable Members, because you are quite right: there is growing evidence that residues of certain medicines in the soil and water pose a major risk to animal and human health, and, furthermore, these residues can also cause environmental damage. What seems to be particularly dangerous are the residues of antimicrobials used in humans and also in livestock farming; they are a particularly big problem. Antimicrobial resistance is a serious and global threat to public health. Their effects go beyond the serious consequences for human and animal health. It also affects agriculture and food production, and thus trade and economic growth. Antimicrobial resistance significantly limits the ability to achieve the Sustainable Development Goals. The Council is aware of the environmental risks associated with the manufacture, use and disposal of medicinal products. It stresses that measures must be in line with the concept of 'health', which takes into account the interaction between human and animal health and the environment. Efforts in just one sector alone are not enough.  For this reason, Ministers in both the Environment And Health Councils welcomed the Commission's communication on the EU's strategic approach to medicines in the environment. In its strategic approach, the Commission has identified six areas where improvements can be made. These improvements, which can be achieved at all stages of the life cycle of medicines, contribute to the achievement of the goal of sustainable development of Europe by 2030.
