In addition, the Commission is right to take the view that, for the purpose of their effectiveness, the measures should not only include controls at the end of the pipeline, i.e. improved waste water treatment. They should also consider the original sources of emissions, such as production, disposal and use.  The EU is a strong global player, particularly on environmental issues, and that is why we all have a duty to strengthen cooperation on this important issue at international level. This, too, is part of the proposed strategy.  The Council looks forward to the new Pharmaceutical Strategy for Europe, which the Commission intends to present this autumn. In this light, we will certainly have to consult. Finally, I would like to point out once again that the Commission's communication on medicinal products in the environment focuses on measures that will start, be initiated and, in some cases, finalised. The Commission has stated that it will take stock of the progress made and decide on further steps. In the light of this proposal, the Council is ready to review all the results and, if necessary, to change its position again in the interests of the environment and in the interests of the protection of animals and human beings.

name: Virginijus Sinkevičius
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank you and the Members for tabling the oral questions and for including this important issue on the agenda of this week’s plenary session. There is overwhelming evidence that traces of pharmaceuticals in water and soil endanger wildlife such as fish, birds and insects, and have an adverse impact on the environment. Pharmaceuticals are now found across Europe’s surface water, and have even reached our drinking water, even if not in quantities that cause immediate concern. Effective medication must remain fully available to citizens. We all agree on this – in the light of the ongoing sanitary crisis probably more than ever. At the same time, we must avoid that there is an undue impact of pharmaceuticals on the environment, because this is the other aspect of which the pandemic has reminded us so strongly: that our health and well—being depends so heavily on a healthy environment. In 2019, the Commission put forward the European strategic approach to pharmaceuticals in the environment. My colleague Stella Kyriakides and I, together, we are leading work within the Commission on this important matter. We are pleased that the Council and Parliament have shown support for the approach, focusing on the entire life cycle of pharmaceuticals. Today, and in reply to the points you raised in your oral questions, I am glad to report that we have made good progress in implementing the different actions we announced and proposed last year. For example, additional pharmaceuticals were included in the revised watch—list under the Water Framework Directive in August this year. For example, additional pharmaceuticals were included for veterinary and medical products, and implementing and delegated acts are currently being drafted under the regulation on veterinary medical products. They also aim to promote more prudent use of antimicrobials and implement new rules on oral medication. The Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) Regulation already reduces emissions during manufacturing of pharmaceuticals through authorisation of used substances. But an effective reduction of the impact of pharmaceuticals on the environment cannot be achieved at EU level without strong engagement also at the level of national health authorities, the pharmaceutical industry and health professionals. In the medicines area, we have started working with Member States’ health ministries, for instance to make sure health professionals are aware of environmental impacts, and we encourage initiatives taken in some Nordic countries to use public procurement as a tool to promote pharmaceuticals that are produced in a green manner. The European Medicines Agency is currently working on updated guidelines on environmental risk assessment for human medical products, and in the waste sector, new guidelines will be developed on collecting schemes for unused medicines. In the area of research, the ongoing Horizon 2020 programme is co—founding solution—oriented research, as illustrated, for example, by a wide—ranging study on contaminants of emerging concern, pathogens and antimicrobial resistance in the water cycle. All EU actions are closely aligned with World Health Organisation (WHO) guidance, and dialogues are established at political and technical level with manufacturing countries outside the EU, offering opportunities to raise concerns regarding the impact associated with the production of pharmaceuticals, especially antibiotics. We will, of course, continue to address pharmaceuticals in the environment in very concrete actions and the various upcoming deliverables under the European Green Deal, like the chemicals strategy and the zero—pollution action plan, and also under the upcoming pharmaceutical strategy, which my colleague Stella Kyriakides is preparing for the end of the year. Also, the farm—to—fork strategy, presented earlier this year, includes an important target. To reduce by 50% by 2030 the overall EU sales of antimicrobials for farmed animals and in aquaculture. Furthermore, in the follow-up to the evaluation of the Urban Waste Water Treatment Directive, we are looking at ways to tackle micropollutants, including pharmaceuticals, which still pass through our waste water treatment plants. All these are concrete examples that illustrate the progress we are making to alleviate the impact of pharmaceuticals in the environment. The issue will remain high on our political agenda, and I can reassure you that we will continue to pursue our efforts together with you, with Member States and with the industry, and, of course, with the professionals, to stay on track and make the necessary progress using both legislative and non—legislative means. I look forward to working very closely with you on this crucial topic.

name: Joanna KOPCIŃSKA
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "There are currently 3,000 pharmaceutical active ingredients on the market. The European Parliament's legal background for pharmaceuticals in the environment is very rich. As foreseen in the Priority Substances Directive, this strategic approach should be followed by proposals for measures taken at EU or Member State level to address the possible environmental impact of pharmaceutical substances, with a view to reducing emissions and losses of such substances entering the aquatic environment, taking into account public health needs and the cost-effectiveness of measures.  We need to promote a new production and post-production awareness of pharmaceutical substances through practices, not so much regulating legal backgrounds as pharmaceuticals are produced, but what happens when they come into contact with the environment.  Of course, all the measures taken should in no way restrict patients' access to medicines. The resolution emphasises this problem well, although it is important to be careful, especially as some elements may be too far-reaching, which, in the context of the current pandemic and the still existing problem of drug shortages, can be challenging.  I support most of the suggestions made in the resolution, especially those that have particular reference to promoting the development of pharmaceuticals that are less harmful to the environment and promote a greener concept. The EU acquis in this regard covers water quality, endocrine disruptors, antibiotic resistance and the Regulation on veterinary medicinal products.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: Before moving on to the next point, I would like to inform you that the Committee on Transport has withdrawn the following requests for urgent procedure under Rule 163 of the Rules of Procedure. name: Othmar KARAS
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by José Manuel Fernandes and Valerie Hayer on behalf of the Committee on Budgets on the draft Council decision on the European Union's own resources system (10025/2020 - C9-0215/2020 - 2018/0135(CNS)) (A9-0146/2020). As you all know, the own resources system is so important, on the one hand, because of the political independence and capacity of the European Union to act, and on the other, for the repayment of the funds now needed for the Next Generation EU fund. I would also like to point out to you that no spontaneous speeches or blue cards are accepted in this debate.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to greet the Council, and also to greet the Commission, all colleagues and all colleagues.  Today we give the green light, with the approval that will take place this week, not only for the introduction of the new own resource but above all for the implementation of the Recovery Fund. With our decision, with our opinion, the Council can immediately proceed with the approval decision-making process, which must be unanimously in the Council, and then ratification by national parliaments in the light of the Constitution of each Member State. We are working very quickly because we want the Recovery Fund ready and available in January 2021 - as early as 1 January - and my question now to the Council, and to the Council representative, the Minister, is: when will the Council adopt this decision? It is that we have called on the Council to immediately adopt this decision on new own resources because we know that ratification usually takes between a year and a half to two years, and it is urgent for the citizens of the European Union who expect this Recovery Fund, it is essential for the economy, for competitiveness, and it is also essential for territorial cohesion , economic and social. This Recovery Fund also brings a new challenge: we have after paying interest and amortization and new own resources are a solution.  We do not want to burden the citizens of the European Union. We also do not want to penalise future generations and cut programmes and cut European Union policies, and so we advocate new own resources on a simple principle: they should be enough to at least pay interest and pay the repayments. We know well that in this Recovery Fund from 2021 to 2027, we will only have 12.9 billion euros for interest, but then by 2058 we will have to pay interest and we will have to pay the repayments, and I hope that the Council will agree with this principle: it takes new own resources to pay the interest and to pay the repayments , because we do not want to ask the Member States for more money, because that would mean asking citizens for more taxes. On the other hand, we cannot penalise future generations, we cannot have policy cuts, and our proposal is simple and based on principles that everyone should also agree with. For example, those who do not pay must pay, and so we ask that the giants of digital be taxed. In addition, we want to strengthen the competitiveness of the European Union and therefore the carbon border mechanism is a possibility for us to strengthen competitiveness, to have revenues and to invite other countries that do not have the same environmental standards to contribute to the objective of combating climate change as well. And therefore, the new own resources, in addition to not penalising the citizens of the European Union, must be in line with the Union's objectives and policies, combating climate change, or enhancing competitiveness. And something that we also consider very important is that, in addition to linking the new own resources to interest and amortisation, it was very important that interest and repayments were counted above the rules of the multiannual financial framework.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, our report answers a legitimate question that everyone is asking. This loan of 750 billion euros is good, it's fabulous, it's historic, really. But who's going to pay it back? Three possibilities. The first possibility is that we are taking money from European programmes to pay off this debt, which we would be pulling out like a ball in our feet until 2058. We should then explain to young people that they can no longer go to Erasmus, to farmers that food sovereignty depends on a reduction in the CAP, to the unemployed that the European Social Fund can no longer finance their reintegration. Who to understand and explain this? The second possibility is that states are repaying this debt through an increase in national contributions, i.e. higher taxes on European citizens. I will be very clear: these two solutions are absolutely unacceptable. Those who have lost their jobs or incomes as a result of the crisis do not have to pay for the recovery, either through additional taxes or through fewer opportunities. For us MEPs, there is a third option, the only viable one for us. To do this, we will have to cross the Rubicon, assume the obvious: that of the creation of new own resources. For all the pro-Europeans, of which I am a member, this is obvious: the evidence that the Union is the optimal level to ensure fiscal justice on a continent-wide scale. It should be noted that we are not reinventing the wheel. What we are defending is only the legal translation of what the Heads of State and Government decided at this summit on 21 July in their politically binding conclusions. So I can already hear, here and there, the proponents of Europe shouting at an imaginary tax on European households. Well, I look you straight in the eye, you who are on the extreme right of this Chamber. Will you be able to explain to your countrymen tomorrow that by dogmatism you refuse to protect their wallets? What an irony for those who self-establish themselves as protectors of the little people against the greats of this world. Do you think it is normal that today the digital giants, which have emerged strengthened from this crisis, still do not contribute to the right level of their profits even though many Europeans have to go and eat away at their savings? Do you think it is normal that large Chinese companies, which export massively to Europe products with a staggering carbon footprint and ultra-aggressive prices, without being subject to the same standards, do not compensate for their environmental impact? Do you still think it is normal for multinationals to practice tax optimisation, financial institutions to speculate excessively or to maintain tax dumping in Europe? Well, I don't think it's normal. It is these players who have to pay for the recovery. I do not want the Europeans to be involved. Of course, this will require political will and courage. Commissioner, Minister, you will understand that this report, which we are debating today, is not just a somewhat complex budget report, a bit 'techno', a bit repulsive. No, what we are discussing today goes much further. What we are defending today is a Europe in which states no longer run out every seven years, during long summits of several days, in order to determine what their rate of return is or how to buy rich but stingy states with indecent discounts. The choice that is about to be made between the States and the European parliamentarians is absolutely crucial. It will determine whether the Union is heading irretrievably towards an international organisation status, such as WHO, whose survival depends solely on the goodwill of its Member States, or whether the Union will finally be armed with its own means to uphold its standards and values, to ensure the next generation of Europeans a prosperous and green future, free of all debt. , if not recognition.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent report, which is a very The year 2020 will go down in the history of a united Europe.  The planned reform of the own resources system is a paradigm shift for the European Union. I hope that we are all aware of this particular responsibility in these extraordinary times. Because we all know that the own resources system, as long as it exists, has been highly controversial in all the institutions of the European Union. Not only with you, honourable Members, but also in the Council and the Commission. What we have now achieved, of course, has something to do with crisis – a serious crisis and an extraordinary crisis that has claimed many lives. Once again, the European Union has managed to send out a proper signal of capacity for action and solidarity. The Next Generation EU programme plays a prominent role in this. A large amount of EUR 750 billion is available to the states, the regions and the people who have suffered the most from the pandemic. But – and Here I can only agree with the honourable rapporteur – the money must, of course, flow quickly so that it arrives where it is really needed.  This requires a new decision on the own resources system. Only this own resources decision gives the Commission the opportunity to borrow the appropriate financial resources on the capital markets. It provides a basis for rapid and comprehensive action in this exceptional crisis. I can assure you, honourable Members, that the Council is aware of its particular responsibility at this difficult time, and you can guess that the decision on this far-reaching reform in the European Council was not easy. But we have achieved this with courage and foresight and solidarity. I would like to introduce you once again to the most important elements of the draft decision. Firstly, the EUR 750 billion in funding under the 'Next Generation EU' programme. However, it is also a question of opening the door to new own resources. There has also been a long and controversial debate on this, the rapporteur. The European Council has taken this wish into account. We will start in 2021 with a new tax, the plastic levy, based on the amount of plastic packaging waste that is not recycled. The draft decision of the European Council goes even further, because other own resources are also outlined. The proposal is on the table for new levies to be launched during the 2021-2027 Multiannual Financial Framework. We are talking about a CO2 limit equalisation levy and also about the digital levy, which you are well aware of. It is also a question of a revised proposal for the emissions trading scheme. In its conclusions, the European Council also identified a possible path for the financial transaction tax to be introduced across the EU. It is precisely this path that shows the opportunity associated with this own resources decision.  I can therefore assure you that we all have a great interest in getting a decision as soon as possible so that the Multiannual Financial Framework, but also the Next Generation EU instrument, can be financed. Once again, I would like to express my thanks to the chairman of the committee, Mr Van Overtveldt, but also to the rapporteur, Mrs Hayer, and to the rapporteur, Mr Fernandes. It was only through their efforts that it was possible for the plenary of the European Parliament to deal with this important decision so quickly. I can assure you – and this was also Mr Fernandes's question – that the Council also wants to bring about a decision as soon as possible, and of course also in the light of your deliberations. However, I would also like to use this debate once again as an opportunity to bring you something that we should not underestimate. We cannot look at and debate the own resources decision in isolation from the overall package, that is, the MFF, the 'Next Generation EU' and also other matters, such as the conditionality of the rule of law. That is why we must keep this package together. I therefore ask you to work hard and constructively with us over the next few days and weeks to ensure that we reach a comprehensive agreement on this overall package as quickly as possible.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: We are now continuing the debate on the report by José Manuel Fernandes and Valerie Hayer on behalf of the Committee on Budgets on a draft Council decision on the European Union's own resources system (A9-0146/2020).

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the European Council in July has taken, as it was already said by several speakers and certainly will be repeated by others, an important step towards reforming the revenue side of the European Union budget.  First, it has taken a pivotal decision to borrow on financial markets to support the post-COVID-19 recovery in the Member States. This will be enabled through the Own Resources Decision. Next Generation EU, together with the core multiannual financial framework, is the largest package ever financed through the European Union budget. It will give an unprecedented, ambitious answer to an unprecedented crisis. Second, the European Council has opened the door for modernisation of the own-resources system, which has not been reformed since 1988. This marks the first modernisation for more than half of our Member States – 16 out of 27.   The European Council endorsed the simplification of the value-added-tax-based own resource, and agreed upon a new own resource based on non-recycled plastic packaging waste as of 2021, and these are only the first steps, as it has also agreed that additional new own resources should be introduced during the next multiannual financial framework period – from 2021-2027 – to finance the repayment of the Next Generation EU borrowing and enable early repayments.  The European Parliament and the Commission have for a long time worked towards reform of the revenue side of the EU budget. It’s very encouraging that the Member States have begun to see what we have been advocating for so long. We have clearly managed to give a new drive to the Own Resource Decision, and I would like to thank the European Parliament for its support, and, may I say, stubbornness.  Let me go more into detail on the report you are set to adopt during this plenary. You foresee an ambitious timeline for the introduction of additional new own resources in your report. We see eye to eye. The Commission concurs with the need to introduce additional new own resources which are closely aligned with our policy priorities and can support the repayment of funds on the Next Generation EU. I am happy to see that there are points of convergence with the European Council conclusions of last July. This makes me hopeful that it will be feasible to introduce new own resources in the short term. In fact, preparatory work has already begun. We spare no efforts to match ambitions with the reality of the political and legal process. As you know, this is also one of the main issues of the trilateral political dialogue meetings on the MFF. Compared to the financial crisis of 2008-2009, Europe’s response to this crisis was exceptional in both strength and speed. You are set to adopt your report less than two months after the European Council at unprecedented pace. It is indeed commendable and thank you for that.  I am confident that the Council and national parliaments will follow your lead, thus facilitating the beginning of borrowing on the Next Generation EU already in January. To conclude, let me just underline that we would want to see the negotiations on the entire package, including the core MFF, progressing with the same impressive pace. Only in this way can we kick-start a recovery phase as of 1 January next year, with an ambitious and comprehensive recovery plan for Europe, so we need it now and not next year.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I welcome Minister Roth and Commissioner Hahn to the European Parliament to this important debate. Firstly, I would like to express on behalf of the Group of the European People’s Party our full support for the report and for the positions expressed by the two rapporteurs, Ms Valerie Hayer and Mr José Manuel Fernandes. Why do we support this report? We support it because the introduction of own resources makes the European Union stronger, it makes it more capable to provide answers and solutions to the problems of the people, because one of the essential tools of the European Union to fulfil the expectations of the people is the budget. And own resources into the budget means a more predictable budget, which means a robust budget in the longer term, capable of financing what the people expect the European Union to finance. This reform of the own resources system and the introduction of new own resources is a position long advocated for by the European Parliament and it is an achievement of the European Parliament and I would like to thank Members of the European Parliament, who over the course of many years have fought for this. Why do we need to introduce own resources exactly now? Because we have indeed made the historic decision to launch the Recovery and Resilience Facility and the whole Next Generation EU package. And the introduction of own resources is the only way to pay for the Recovery and Resilience Facility without negatively affecting the EU budget in the future, because we do not want to see payments to farmers, payments to communes, to villages, to researchers, to Erasmus students, to be affected in the future. Neither do we want to see the security of our borders or our ambitions in the area of greening be affected. This is why we have to act now on own resources and this is why we, as the European Parliament, demand a binding calendar for the introduction of own resources, legally binding. And this should finance at least the repayment of interest and of the whole Next Generation EU over the course of the next years. We did our work. The ball is now in the field of the Council. Minister Roth, we expect to you, as the incumbent Presidency, to act swiftly so that we fulfil our goal to have an ambitious Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) and the own resources enter into force on 1 January 2021.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, Commissioner Hahn, Minister Roth, I have already lost count of the years we have been asking for serious negotiations on the financing of the European budget and on how to set up a basket of taxes to allow ambitious budgets to be held without relying on or drowning national coffers. I think in these years we have given them endless reasons to get it going, but we haven't just moved forward yet.  In 2003, negotiating the current financial framework, we reached an agreement to launch this high-level group chaired by Mario Monti. We already have the study and we can't delay it anymore. It is a matter of fiscal justice, because it is not possible that it is the usual ones who keep public policies with their taxes, and that it is the usual ones who escape to contribute.  It is a matter of efficiency, because the establishment of certain taxes only makes sense at European level under the umbrella of the single market; it is a matter of climate policy, because those who pollute the most must pay more and must also contribute to the financing of the fair transition. And I would say that it is almost a matter of survival of the European project, because in this crisis, at last, a strong economic response has been given with that great agreement on the Recovery Plan at the July European Council.  But public finances are being overwhelmed by the spending needs that this new crisis entails and the ones we are dragging from previous crises, so there is no other way, there is no other solution. Yes or yes, we need to close an agreement on UNION funding, because we don't have plan B here either.

name: Luis GARICANO
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. "Mr Vice-President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, on behalf of my group, Renew Europe, I would like to express my enthusiastic and unconditional support for this resolution and the work of our group's rapporteur, Valérie Hayer, and the rapporteur Fernandes of the People's Group.  The satisfaction is due to the fact that, thanks to this Decision, we are going to allow the European Union to borrow EUR 750 billion which will finance the joint fight against the economic consequences of the pandemic. But this satisfaction is coupled with a deep concern, which I share with the colleagues who have just spoke, and is that we do not have the resources to pay off the debt we are issuing. The European Union does not have the European resources to repay this European debt at the moment. Like the United States after the War of Independence, every seven years here, member states have to contribute unanimously and voluntarily to our request for money to continue to exist. That's not acceptable. This form of funding creates unacceptable tensions between Member States and it is time to change it. It is time for European debt to be paid with taxes, not with contributions from European citizens — from Dutch, French, etc. citizens — but with taxes that they pollute and do not pay and those who do not face the taxes they should face. These are the resources we are proposing in this Parliament.  The Council is committed to putting these resources in place. We hope that during the first half of 2021 we will be able to work with the Commission and the Council to get them up and running as soon as possible.

name: Hélène LAPORTE
text: On behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Minister, which has been diverted from its original objectives, the reform of own resources is the Trojan horse of the European Union in the creation of disguised European taxes. The European Commission ignores the fact that the average consumer will bear the consequences in terms of unemployment and inflation on prices. The border carbon tax will mean that Chinese or American multinationals will pass on their higher costs to their prices. Unchanged since 1988 in its operation, the own resources system had initially been the subject of a laudable reform which compensated for the benefit of the Member States the dumpings we suffer in ecological or fiscal matters. A discussion paper had been issued in 2017 in this direction, advocating the creation of new own resources, as the funding of the budget was mainly based on gross national income and therefore on the Member States. But under the cover of the economic crisis following the current pandemic, the Commission has succeeded in getting a mutualised loan repaid by self-sustaining revenues accepted, to be created, and which will turn into a sustainable tax for its own benefit. The picture of the Europeanisation of national public finances that the European Union has been preparing in petto for several years is now complete, with the creation of European taxes that do not say their names. But the fight is not over because, admittedly, Germany is reticent about the carbon tax and Ireland is reticent about the digital tax, unless the qualified majority replaces the rule of unanimity, yet engraved in the marble of the Brussels Treaties. In this case, in its budgetary and fiscal integration with means, it must be admitted, unglamorous, will then still triumph the distrust of the peoples towards it.

name: David CORMAND
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are in a particular moment, what is called momentum, - we have even heard of a Hamiltonian moment. It is true that today, with this report, it is a form of culmination of a long-running struggle that many and many MePs have long seen that not controlling our revenues is a democratic anomaly that needs to be repaired. It is during this crisis that we measure how essential it is that we are no longer dependent on the goodwill of the Council and the States in order to be in control of our revenues and therefore in control of our expenditure. This report says that it is time for Parliament and the European Union to have its own resources, but above all it says that it is time for us to have fair resources. Because today, in our various states, taxes are too often, precisely, on ordinary citizens. What is now being proposed to the Council is to finally have this fair taxation, one that attacks those who are now exempt from tax. It is the financial transaction tax, it is the GAFAM tax and it is also a tax at our borders, precisely to protect the companies in our territories who make the effort to be better known in social and environmental matters. My dear friends, if we are to be able to get out of this crisis, we must implement this fair taxation. The work of the co-speakers, both Mrs Hayer and Mr Fernandes, reflects parliament's will and I say this very quietly: there will be no blackmail. We will not accept that the Council will put us in front of the fait accompli, we want this fair taxation. I would add, for the countries that would be in a hurry - and they are right - to have the revenues from the stimulus package, that today's just taxation, today's own resources, are the solidarity of tomorrow. And if we postpone it — I heard that we only opened the door, I heard that there were only sketches of ways to go and I heard the date of 2027 — you know that tax justice, the ecological transition later, is ecology too late. So there is an urgent need for us to act and we will be vigilant here in Parliament so that this momentum will really translate into a change in the functioning of our institutions.

name: Bogdan RZOŃCA
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent Dear Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. The conclusions of the European Council of July this year really poured a lot of optimism into us. The peoples of the European Union have heard the prime ministers' agreement and therefore their willingness to help the economies of individual countries, cities or the unemployed.  We cannot therefore stand still, because the pandemic crisis continues and the first wave is behind us, perhaps there will be another wave, so we should act reactively and quickly. We just can't stand still. Let us start using the financial instruments already prepared to combat the economic drama, because Europe will lose and the entire reputation of the European Union will also be lost. At the same time, Mr President, I would like to add that we cannot harm poorer countries, because the plastic tax agreed at EUR 0.8 and now presented as EUR 2 is unfavourable at the moment. Likewise, the emissions trading tax introduced from 2021 is also unfavourable, and I want to make this clear. For example, Poland will cost around EUR 10 billion.

name: José GUSMÃO
text: gue/NGL Group. – Mr President, we all know that without own resources the Recovery Fund will be nothing more than a mountain of debt which will sooner or later fall on the Member States, and it is therefore important that Parliament approves a binding timetable. Only that this calendar that is proposed looks more like the Greek calendas. The carbon emissions market will be handled very quickly, but the digital tax, the financial transactions, the CCTB on multinationals, these will have to wait many years. Parliament leaves for a number of years now what it should start doing today.  In the case of the CCTB, the tax base for multinationals, the European Parliament refers this dossier, this very important resource itself, to its next term of office. In other words, this European Parliament is preparing to decide that it will not decide.  It is time – and this timetable is at this time – for the European Parliament to understand the urgency of these own resources and to set itself a timetable in line with that urgency.

name: Antoni COMÍN I OLIVERES
text: – Mr President, it has taken a crisis like this for the European Union to start making decisions that have been waiting too long — thirty-two years since the last change in the system of own resources. With a 20th-century income model, it is impossible to meet the challenges of the 21st century.  We need more and better own resources for many reasons. At the outs and away, to return the money from the recovery instrument. The alternative would be to increase national contributions, further complicating the discussion on net donors and recipients, or to reduce the Union budget, i.e. less Europe: unacceptable.  We urgently need more own resources to give the Union greater financial autonomy over the Member States, but also to combat climate change, in favour of harmonisation and fiscal justice or in favour of financial stability. Thus, the July Council proposal is not sufficient. Plastic waste tax is not enough; it is not enough to talk about carbon border tax, digital rate or allowances as a possibility: they are an overriding necessity. And, as this Parliament proposes, we also need the fee on financial transactions. Finally, and I conclude, we need to start building a true European tax system.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by It should be noted that our debate today is really about two issues that are related, but two. Firstly, it concerns the Council's decision to launch the procedure to create an opportunity to build a new Next Generation EU fund.  Secondly, what this entails is the question of building new own revenues in the future. This must be borne in mind, because this second debate obviously requires a different type of decision and agreement between Parliament and the Council, and the former actually takes time. It also takes time because, when we were working and discussing the 2021-2027 budget, when we had not yet talked about this fund at all, we were planning certain expenditures. Then the budget was sort of frozen or reduced and we were informed that it would be compensated with the help of the fund. At the moment, it appears that if ratification does not go according to plan, the fund could be seriously threatened.  I would therefore like to make it very clear that, since the Minister and the Commissioner are saying that we are talking about one package, which we agree with, then in this package everything must be interconnected and everything is dependent on each other, which means that Parliament's consent to the multiannual budget must be linked to creating an opportunity for a new fund. Without this fund, the budget is too small and not enough for some of the actions that we have foreseen. If the package, let us treat it in a package and we are ready for this type of conversation and start work very, very intensively.

name: Margarida MARQUES
text: – Mr President, Minister Roth, Commissioner Hahn, colleagues, the financial architecture of the European crisis response is based on a key pillar: own resources. It is urgent and necessary and cannot compromise the future of generations. That is why we must do everything we can to mobilise new own resources and we look forward to a swift initiative on the Council's side. Own resources aligned with the European Union's political priorities, such as the Green Deal or the digital transition. The new own resources should now serve to pay for next generation EU commitments and to finance reimbursement by Member States, so as not to create added difficulties after 2028. And in the near future they should be used to finance the European Union budget. This is also the opportunity for a fairer tax system, it is the opportune time to launch a tax on financial transactions and a tax on large digital companies. One and the other should contribute to the financing of the European Union budget.

name: Sandro GOZI
text: Mr President, against unpredictability, the remedy lies in the ability to make and keep promises, as Hannah Arendt quite rightly said. In July, you, the Commission, the Council, made a promise: to finance the recovery plan with new resources by making polluters, the digital giants and those of finance pay. Now let's do what we said. You want to make Europe fair and popular, so keep that promise quickly. The alternative is to increase national contributions, to ask taxpayers more or to cut European budgets even further. If you want to make the Union more unpopular, that would be the right way. But no, this is not an alternative. The effectiveness and credibility of the plan depends on it. A binding timetable for introducing new own resources is needed before the end of the year. And finally, let us respect the treaties: the own resources are anchored there, the current ones are very dated, so it is high time to put in place new ones.

name: Joachim KUHS
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Thank you for all the speeches we have heard. They amaze me a little. Mr Roth, Minister of State, you spoke of a paradigm shift. In the documents I read about a quantum leap that we have here. Yes, that really is the case. But that worries me. I am concerned about this because the last time we had such a quantum leap – that was before the crisis in 2008 – you struck many rules to save the euro and Greece, and in the end there were breaches of the treaty. The German Federal Constitutional Court has confirmed this.  And now, what's next? Now new taxes are coming. Now comes a new statehood of the EU. They are changing the face of the EU. You want to collect more taxes of your own, and what happens then? I would like to warn you against doing so. This will lead to the weakening of the national states, the Member States, and the fact that their own contributions will ultimately not be reduced, but will be increased even further.  And now the following is happening: such taxes tend never to stop. I would remind you of the champagne tax introduced 100 years ago to strengthen the imperial navy. This tax still exists today. Please spare us from new taxes.

name: Derk Jan EPPINK
text: Mr President, the corona crisis is being used to introduce a new European tax. That's what I'm worried about. It starts with a European plastic waste tax and then there are many other forms of taxation that are in the box: a European digital tax, a European financial transaction tax, a European CO2 border tax and so on. These European taxes actually serve as a growth hormone for the creation of a European state – which some speakers also object to – where all power goes with money and so on. Of course, the approval of the various Member States and mine is needed: the approval of the House of Representatives and the Senate. I am very curious about the position of the CDA and the VVD, because in the Netherlands they say that they are opposed to the European debt community, but in Brussels they are happy to contribute to this. So I ask them, where do they actually stand? And if they don't have an answer, their masks fall.

name: Marc BOTENGA
text: Mr President, the question you are asking us today is this: do you want, or do you not want a European tax, a new European tax? Personally, I say that there is no quick answer to this question which is much more complex than that. In fact, the question is: who will pay for this European tax? And what I'm going to say is not necessarily going to please the right, but the question is that it's time today to take the financial transaction tax out of the drawers —a real tax on financial transactions and not a Canada Dry version, a Coke Light version, no! A real tax, which, for once, makes big speculators pay rather than always workers, rather than always those who run our society. A tax that targets the financial markets and allows us to mobilize public funds and make them available to jobs, the real economy and people. For once, rather than lie down against the financial markets, let's tax them!

name: Niclas HERBST
text: Mr President, Commissioner, Minister of State, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his work and for the work he has You were right to point out that we must, of course, look at the whole thing in the package. We have already received the Commission's Multiannual Financial Framework in May 2018. This means that we now have this time pressure is really not Parliament's fault, but because there are very different views in the Member States. I do not envy you for your task in the Presidency of the Council to reconcile this. The danger then is always that there are formula compromises. We are, of course, seeing this in the debate on the rule of law. We must now also make it quite clear that new own resources must not be synonymous with us regulating something later on, but we must now have a legally binding timetable and we must also state very clearly what is at stake. It is a question, as has been said many times, of funding Next Generation EU. The joke is that Next Generation EU goes to the Member States to a very large extent. It is therefore not a question of us here in Brussels, so to speak, wanting to acquire new competences and distribute new funds, but rather of funding this programme, which benefits the Member States. If we give the green light, we will not do so because we are not aware of the strategic importance or because we are naive. We are certainly not doing it because we are so enthusiastic about what has been presented so far, but because we know the responsibility that we have here.  I ask the Council very warmly and I also call on it to shoulder its own responsibilities. You can only do that if you take Parliament seriously. We are ready for discussion. Take us seriously.

name: Pierre LARROUTUROU
text: Mr President, dear friends, for health, for climate, for jobs: in all our countries we need money to win these three battles. The emergency plan decided by the heads of state in July is historic. Historical, but totally inadequate. That is why Parliament is now demanding real progress on own resources. By 2024, the Financial Transaction Tax (FTT) can bring in $50 billion each year. 50 billion each year means 15 billion to pay down the common debt linked to the emergency plan and 35 billion each year to reverse the budget cuts made by the heads of state to finance the Green Pact and all the priorities of the European Union. If all Member States could be told that the common debt would be repaid by the FTT, ratification would be much easier. And if that $50 billion arrives as early as 2024, the risk of falling back into recession after the emergency plan would be much lower. The FTT directive has been on the table since 2011. This week, Parliament will vote on this ambitious timetable and we will be campaigning in all our countries to push heads of state to accept it. In 2014, Angela Merkel called on the British to renounce their veto on the FTT. Last week, Merkel reiterated that she wanted an agreement this year on the FTT. This is also Parliament's aim: an agreement this year on the financial transaction tax.

name: Caroline NAGTEGAAL
text: Mr President, when politicians say that exceptional circumstances call for exceptional measures, I am wary because very often this reasoning is used as an excuse to implement policies without any consequences being considered. That's the way it is now. When it comes to the possible introduction of new European taxes, I think we all agree. Companies also have to pay their fair share in taxes, just like all citizens. But a large part of my colleagues here in Parliament are convinced that new taxes, such as a financial transaction tax or European corporation tax, will spare the people of the European Union. And I can predict that new taxes will end up on the left or the right of hard working people, so let's just not do that. Exceptional circumstances require careful, thoughtful measures at this time.

name: Teuvo HAKKARAINEN
text: – Mr President, how does the EU intend to scrape together the money to repay hundreds of billions of coronavirus loans? The only source of money on which there is some agreement is a plastic tax. Some Member States will also receive a reduction. According to the Council, other new funds will not be available until years from 2023. This is irresponsible and violates the Union's own rule on the balance between revenue and expenditure in the EU budget. If no new sources of income are found, the loan will be repaid with increased EU membership fees. As is customary for socialists, problems will be transferred to the arms of future governments. Only the loan of this one crisis will be paid for decades. I'm sure there'll be new ones. The coronavirus recovery package can still be cancelled. Let's get back to the path of compliance. No common debt, and therefore no EU tax.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Minister, i would like to thank you for your comments. Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in the debate on the Union's own resources, I would like to remind you that the compromise reached at the Council meeting in July was based on several principles that we should respect here in Parliament. First, the new sources of revenue of the Union budget should not directly burden member states' budgets, but should be linked to the benefits of the common market, so that, first, it should be a digital tax or a financial transaction tax.  The council's levy on unprocessed plastic has reached consensus only because it has been proposed at a relatively low level and a mechanism has been put in place to limit its regressivity. Thirdly, the Council rejected the introduction of an ETS-based own resource, as it is the revenue of national budgets from which the funds are allocated to actions related to the implementation of the Union's climate and energy policy. Only parliament's upholding of these arrangements gives the chance that they will be adopted by the parliaments of the 27 Member States. Unfortunately, Parliament's report is moving away from them in many places.

name: Karlo RESSLER
text: – Mr President, massive investments in the digital and green transformation through the historic Recovery Plan should be a crucial growth engine and hope for Next Generation Europe. In this unprecedented crisis this will not be possible without a credible repayment plan. This is why the reform of the system of own resources is really a pre-condition for the success of the whole package, of the whole concept. A strong message of European solidarity towards those who are most hit by the crisis needs to be followed now by a message of responsibility towards all Europeans, but especially towards the youth. We need a swift reaction. A swift ratification so the entrepreneurs, workers, farmers, but also other recipients, can benefit from the assistance provided as soon as possible. At the same time we cannot sacrifice our long-term priorities and investments. Three decades since the last introduction of a new own resource, a levy on plastics is an important first step but it is certainly not enough for the sustainability of the repayment. We need a clear and fair repayment plan, because otherwise cuts to the most important and most successful EU programmes will jeopardise the future of Europe’s new generation, and that is certainly not the case.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, by agreeing to a EUR 750 billion package, EU leaders have crossed the Rubicon. Yet, just as Caesar’s success was far from guaranteed, this package alone might not bring us the recovery that we wish and the sustainability that we need. We may run out of steam before we reach our destination, and without proper own resources we will run out of steam. To avoid cutting back on future EU spending, the EU should have income to repay its debts, and this income should derive from areas where European action is of added value. To make polluters pay a fair price, to make digital companies and large corporates pay a fair share, we need European action including a Common Consolidated Corporate Tax Base, and by asking for this now, the European Parliament is paving the way for a real success.

name: Billy KELLEHER
text: – Mr President, last July, the leaders in the Council agreed a EUR 1.8 trillion package. That’s the Multiannual Financial Framework and also the recovery fund of EUR 750 billion. We accept that own resources have to fund this, but we have to be very cautious and honest in our debate here and in our discussions. The fact of the matter is that revenue and taxation is a Member State competency and that has to be debated in a very careful manner. We can’t just absolve that fact in the Treaties that underpin the European Union.  There is acknowledgment that own resources must be expanded to fund the recovery package – the border adjustment tax, digital levy, the energy trading scheme and a financial transaction tax.  These particular issues must be discussed, but at the same time we do not want to run headlong into introducing taxes that could put the European Union at a competitive disadvantage with its international competitors. Bear in mind that the OECD is in discussions about an international tax obligation of countries across the globe for a fair and equitable tax system, but don’t tie the hands of the European Union in advance of those recommendations being made by the OECD.

name: Gunnar BECK
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the commissioner for his work and for the work he has The EU wants new taxes: EU plastic taxes, financial taxes, carbon tax and digital taxes.  The EU Parliament also seeks own funds from corporate taxes. Eu countries already have the HIGHEST tax rates in the OECD, but the EU finances escalating spending in breach of the Treaty. Germany is the main contributor to the EU budget and debt. The German state pays and makes its citizens poor. And so Germans have the lowest median wealth in the eurozone, the lowest property ownership rate, and the world's highest payroll taxes and taxes. But if your EU tax colony Germany is bled out, what then?

name: Charlie WEIMERS
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr After 20 years in the bourgeoisie, there are some basic economic principles that I do not compromise on: limit the tax burden. Don't live on borrowed money. Not in debt for future generations. You Moderates have accepted Prime Minister Löfven's summer fiasco at the negotiating table here in Brussels. You are involved in debting future generations, borrowing subsidies and giving the EU the right to tax. You are sacrificing bourgeois principles on the altar of europe. You failed the European Board. You failed when you voted against the SD motion against the EU's irregular indebtedness of children and grandchildren in order to shovel out billions of subsidies to mismanaged economies. Tomas Tobé: It is not too late for the Moderates to change their minds. Support our proposal here in Brussels to stop EU borrowing. Support us in the Riksdag. Together, we can save future generations billions of debts and EU taxes.

name: Kris PEETERS
text: Mr President, an unprecedented crisis requires unprecedented action. That is why we are negotiating a budget with an ambitious recovery package. Through low interest rates and the high credit worthiness of the European Commission, we will borrow cheaply to invest in our European economy. But the repayment of the recovery plan must be timely and correct. We therefore call for fair own income and a binding timetable. Importers of, for example, cheap steel who do not respect our environmental standards will contribute to the recovery through a CO2 tax. Digital multinationals, which pay little tax here and make a profit in the European single market, will also have to contribute to our recovery. This European recovery plan is a historic opportunity that we must seize. If the European Union succeeds in reviving the economy, we can win the trust of the citizens. But if we fail in repayment, each country will be thrown back on its own, and we must prevent this at all costs.

name: Nils UŠAKOVS
text: – Mr President, Europe has a unique experience of overcoming the deepest crises and becoming stronger afterwards. Actually the European Union itself was created as a result of the most dramatic period in human history. Right now Brexit, COVID, economic depression and instability at our borders create both incentives and opportunities to reform the Union, to make it a world power: democratic, welfare-based, and climate and carbon neutral. We need a road map now, a clear timetable and commitment from Member States to introduce an ambitious basket of own resources, taxing speculators, polluters, the super-rich and multinational corporations. The debate about own resources is the debate about our future in the long term. If Member State governments fail, we will end up making ordinary Europeans, their children and grandchildren pay for COVID, for Brexit and for any other crisis we will face, making, at the end of the day, the European Union a second-level player, which is the opposite of what Europeans dream about and deserve. Good luck Minister, and good luck Commissioner.

name: Herve JUVIN
text: Mr President, democracy in Europe, in Great Britain as in France, is linked to the principle of tax consent by legitimately elected parliaments and assemblies and representatives of the sovereign people. Whatever the qualities of the report before us - for my part, I agree with a number of its proposals on the carbon tax, the GAFAM tax and also the tax on speculative financial transactions - we will oppose this project of own resources. What for? Because, if I know European nations, European peoples to whom I recognize sovereignty over their territory and in their nation, I know no European people, and European sovereignty is a political artifice and a vain word of opinion. That is why we will oppose this principle of own resources, which is not honest because the resources envisaged will not be sufficient to repay the debt, which does not seem democratic to us because it is not validated by a democratically elected parliament, and which seems to us to represent a dangerous coup de force for the economic governance of the European Union and a serious precedent against our nations.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, we can already feel that the new European loan and new own resources are almost synonyms, right? I mean, let’s be honest, we need own resources in order to pay back the loan that we are going to take, because the situation for me looks like the crisis of 2007. You’re buying a house and then you’re facing the risk of not having an income to pay it back. We don’t want our children to pay it, nor the bank to take it away. So we need own resources to secure the future of the Union without taking hostage the budget and the payments of the Member States. That’s one thing. By midnight tomorrow, this House I expect to unanimously adopt the position of the Parliament on REACT—EU. This is yet another example of cohesion policy securing the societies and the help of the Member States because of COVID – another example of cohesion policy saving our people. A huge part of that fund, of REACT—EU, is going to be taken from that loan. That is another reason to talk about carefully designed own resources which are going to support the budget without taking hostage the Member States’ payments to our budget. So we need another thing. We need the rule of law in that regulation, because our citizens have to be sure that there is transparency in every cent that we are going to spend. The European Union is not like a cat; we don’t have nine lives, so we have to act now.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Minister and the honourable Members for all their interventions and input. As I have said in other encounters, I don’t shy away from an open debate and very much value the position of the European Parliament. As we continue the modernisation of the own resources system, I’m sure we will have many more opportunities to discuss this important issue in the future. Without delving into technical details, let me offer some final remarks. As you know, negotiations are currently ongoing between the Parliament, the German Presidency and the Commission. In that sense, the Commission will continue to carry out its role and duty as an honest broker, and stands ready to offer all the necessary assistance. All the institutions agree on the need for new own resources to finance the repayment of the borrowing. Therefore, I believe that it should be possible to agree on a powerful political commitment to own resources as part of the final MFF package. Let me recall that the Multiannual Financial Framework and Next Generation EU legislation is a package. Only quick approval of all – and may I stress all – legal texts would allow the launching of the EU recovery plan. Interinstitutional negotiations must progress as fast as possible and will require the willingness to make compromises on all sides. As you recall, on 9 May we celebrated 70 years since the Schuman Declaration, a founding moment for our Union. Robert Schuman reminds us of our historical responsibility as Europeans. As he said, and I quote, ‘Europe will not be made all at once, or according to a single plan. It will be built through concrete achievements which first create a de facto solidarity’. Next Generation EU, the recovery plan for Europe, is our opportunity for a concrete achievement, creating real European solidarity, and I think it’s high time to seize this opportunity for citizens, for businesses, for Europe.

name: Michael Roth
text: President-in-Office of the Council. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent Do you seriously have the impression that we do not take you seriously? I am a little surprised at this concern, which one Member here said he had to express.  We all know that without your support, without a majority in the European Parliament, there will be no multiannual financial framework, next generation EU, or own resources reform. And please take us at our word: we want negotiations on an equal footing. I would like to thank all the Members who have once again referred to the ambitious timetable. We are available 24 hours a day, seven days a week, to get reasonable and courageous results with you. Our schedule didn't taste good to all of you either. We have said that we want to be ready by the end of September. That is our aim. Because, of course, we know that the national ratification procedures will not be easy. I say this as a representative of a country – federally structured – in which not only the German Bundestag, but also the representative body of the German states, has to agree. This is very ambitious.  But we are speaking, not only with you, but above all with the citizens, who have suffered massively from the crisis. In this respect, I would like to contradict the Members who give the impression that we are behaving irresponsibly towards the younger generation. This proposal is generational. The money that we want to borrow with your support is intended to combat unemployment among young people, to build better health care and to strengthen solidarity in the European Union. We don't leave anyone behind! What do young people get from being unemployed now, but we may be taking on less debt in the next 20 years? We must make this decision now. In our decisions, we have placed the interests of the young generation in the focus of our decisions. Yes, raising taxes, introducing taxes is probably the most controversial thing in a democracy. We must justify this to the citizens. It takes majorities to do this. That is a little easier for you, but we need unanimity in the Council. We need the approval of all the Member States, of all the national parliaments, where ratification via national parliaments is necessary. Nor do we act anywhere in a vacuum, but we act on the basis of Article 311 of the EU Treaty. It lays down exactly what a reform of own resources should look like. This is by no means a coup or an attack on democracy, as certain circles, not only here in the European Parliament, but also in some national parliaments, are constantly trying to persuade the citizens, that is democracy. I do not know how we should make the bond of democracy in the European Union even stronger than to impose a special responsibility on the national parliaments – and not just on the European Parliament or the Commission or the Council.  However, it is not just a question of new levies and new revenue. Yes, that is important, honourable Members. But we also want to take forward the socio-ecological transformation of Europe. We want to do more for social justice, because if we really introduce the plastic tax, it will also have a steering effect. We want to help recycle even more plastic in the future.  Of course, there is also a consequence: then revenue may fall again. But that depends on how you, how we work together to design these taxes in detail. What these levies, these taxes, should look like exactly, what the roadmap that the Commission intends to present will also be at the heart of the negotiations between the three institutions, Parliament, the Council and the Commission. We press the Tube, we take our responsibilities seriously. I am pleased with the many, many signals of constructive support and that in the end there is a little argument about this, which should be self-evident in the importance of these issues.  Thank you very much for this important debate. I have learned a great deal, and we are taking this into the negotiations between the Council, the Commission and Parliament, and I look forward to a positive conclusion soon.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: Rapporteur. – All States are net beneficiaries of the European Union, even those who contribute the most and this pedagogy, this truth, should be told to all citizens of the European Union and the Council does not always do so and, usually, when there are those lengthy Councils, hide from their citizens that even those who are so-called "net contributors" receive much more than they put in the Budget of the European Union and it is to see , the benefits of the internal market. Mr Roth, I have appreciated your words and your availability, but we know that the German Presidency is not the Council, or not everyone in the Council has the same will, but I am sure that you will be able to take - drag, that is the word - the other Member States.  The European Parliament has been waiting, spoke of the rule of law. We have been waiting for two years and it is a legislative codecision procedure, this is a package, yes, ma'am, but of course we will only give consent to the multiannual financial framework, and I assume that the Council will also, if there is a Recovery Fund. The Recovery Fund hides the weaknesses and smallness of the multiannual financial framework and, from that point of view, we consider it a package.  But we must move forward now with what takes longer and, in particular, the ratification by national parliaments with regard to the authorisation for the European Commission to go to the markets and, because we do not want to cut back or penalise citizens in the future, we propose a binding timetable, and then I also ask for the Council's help and understanding, there can be no declarations or proclamations , it has to be a binding timetable that is in the interinstitutional agreement and, in this way, we protect the future of the European Union and citizens from now on, and we will get the necessary revenue to meet the challenges and to pay the interest and repayment of the loan that will be made.

name: Valérie HAYER
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, Commissioner, Minister, ladies and gentlemen, on Wednesday, in voting on our report, we will in fact allow The Member States to start the ratification process. In fact, we will ratify this stimulus package to give the green light to this historic common borrowing. After this vote on Wednesday evening, we can say that we have taken responsibility, that we have worked quickly and that the ball is now in the court of the national parliaments. Around this report, we were able, together with my colleague José Manuel Fernandes, a Portuguese Christian Democrat, to bring together our colleagues: Elisabetta Gualmini, Italian socialist, David Cormand, French ecologist, Dimitrios Papadimoulis, from the Greek radical left. And from this radical left to the right, through our political group Renew Europe, we have been able to unite around this principle: the debt will have to be repaid by the new own resources. Of course, as has been pointed out, a legally binding timetable will be absolutely necessary to ensure their introduction. This demonstrates one thing: own resources are not a question of left or right. Own resources are a matter of loving and sustaining Europe, it is a question of assuming, of having a sense of responsibility in protecting the economies of Europeans. It is a demonstration of the ability to rise, to look beyond national interests alone, in the interest of Europeans, whether they are French, Dutch, Romanian or Danish. This is the demand that we expect of the Member States to get out of the unanimity in which they are entangled - it must be said, they are entangled on this subject. But this time, they will have no choice, not only because we will be intransigent, Minister, but because the States know that any other solution would strengthen the Alternativ for Germany, the National Rally in France, Geert Wilders' PVV in the Netherlands and all the Eurosceptics, who would now have a boulevard to determine, and I say even to sacrifice - we already know that we are European policies. This, every pro-European must fight it with force. You can count on us, Commissioner, on our stubbornness to move forward on the issue of own resources. Minister, you can count on our availability to move forward constructively but demandingly in these negotiations. Our report is a plea for a Union that protects the savings of its fellow citizens and asserts itself before the greats of this world. That is happening now.
