name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: Writing. – The Fidesz-KDNP delegation has already indicated after the July EP resolution that it is contrary to the interests of hundreds of millions of European citizens, and therefore the position of the majority of the EP, which sharply attacks it, rejects the historic budget agreement reached in the European Council. All European countries have been hit by the second wave of the epidemic, so it is even more important to adopt the seven-year framework budget and the recovery fund as quickly as possible. The majority of the EP does not support the Council agreement contrary to common European interests and has even irresponsibly challenged it. This attack results in irreparable delays in the joint management of the social and economic crisis caused by the new coronavirus epidemic in the EU. Another stage in this grossly irresponsible parliamentary procedure: the majority of the EP has called for the introduction of EU revenues that, in stark contrast to the views of the vast majority of Member States, would replace the current system, based on payments that depend more heavily on the economic development of the Member States. Most of these new own resources proposals would take more resources away from poorer Member States for the benefit of the rich. Once again, the majority of the EP is reaching for the instrument of self-serving political pressure, wanting a mandatory timetable for the introduction of new revenues for all without which it does not accept the historic decision of the Heads of State or Government. The EP does not have any real powers either: the representatives of the 27 Member States decide on this issue and the national parliaments approve and ratify it.

name: Leszek MILLER
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The draft Council decision under discussion envisages increasing the Union's budgetary capacity and establishing a new basket of own resources. The adoption of this act is necessary because it determines the possibility for the Commission to raise EUR 750 billion on the financial markets to fund the EU's reconstruction fund.  The European Parliament has been calling for a change in the way the EU budget is financed for many years by reducing the contributions of The Member States, which are now the lion's share of the Union budget (around 70%). This would change the dynamics of budgetary negotiations, in which Member States' representatives attach less importance to the shape of Community policies and focus mainly on obtaining a favourable balance of their own commitments to the EU budget and the resources they receive from it. The EU's additional own resources, including the proceeds of the new taxes, should make it possible to repay loans taken out by the Commission. Failure to do so, in turn, will mean that the debt will have to be repaid from member states' contributions, and this will force cuts in Community policies. I therefore share Parliament's consistent position, which insists on the introduction of new sources of budgetary revenue.  Unfortunately, the Treaty procedure for the adoption of this Council decision necessitates its ratification by all national parliaments. This creates the risk that the parliaments of the so-called frugal countries, which are sceptical about how the funds from the reconstruction fund will be distributed, may be rejected by any country reluctant to establish a mechanism for budgetary conditionality.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The European Commission forecasts that the European Union's economy will shrink by 8.3% in 2020. We must therefore respond jointly at EU level to the economic, social and health crisis caused by the coronavirus. One of the most important elements of this is the EU framework budget for 2021-2027 and the Next Generation EU recovery facility with a budget of EUR 750 billion. In order to ensure that the financing of the Recovery Fund does not result in increasing member states' contributions to the EU budget, it is essential to reform the EU's own resources. Even before the negotiations, the European Parliament called for the adoption of a number of new sources of revenue, such as the CST, the taxation of digital services, the financial transaction tax, the income from the ETS, the plastic contribution and the mechanism to counteract the carbon intensity of imported consumer goods. Unfortunately, however, there are governments in member states such as the Orban government, which threatens that if the payments of the next MFF are subject to stricter conditions than previously agreed rule of law, the Hungarian Parliament will not approve the own resources decision, which would put the whole aid package at risk. We cannot allow populist forces to blackmail us with a means of verifying compliance with the criteria arising from the EU Founding Treaties, thereby threatening to properly deal with the damage caused by Covid19 in the EU.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Mr Beazley on beazley: Nikos Androulakis, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Consumer Policy, public health and food safety, on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Decision No 1313/2013/EU on a Union civil protection mechanism (COM(2020)0220 - C9-0160/2020 - 2020/0097(COD)) (A9-0148/2020).

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Union's civil protection mechanism is a practical expression of solidarity. It supports states in need of high-risk emergencies: natural disasters, health crises and even possible biological, chemical or nuclear accidents. Until now, its action has focused on tackling forest fires. After all, rescEU was born as an idea after the deadly fires in Portugal in 2017. At the time, Europe seemed powerless to help one of its members. But also in the tragedy in Mati, in 2018, where over a hundred people died within minutes. Even the most sceptical at the time understood that we needed greater European intervention, both in terms of prevention and in terms of response. In 2020 we experienced a gigantic historical reversal, one that marks entire generations and changes attitudes and attitudes: the COVID-19 pandemic. Who expected that after a century of rapid scientific and technological development, history would not repeat itself as a farce but as a tragedy? Hundreds of thousands of people around the world, including over 140,000 fellow citizens, have killed us. The economic and social costs are still undetermined. We must therefore act proactively, even for the unforeseeable.  The changes we voted on a year and a half ago strengthened the mechanism, which became visible during the pandemic. His action saved our credibility when, at the beginning of the crisis, governments were making disappointingly unpleasant decisions. At that time we transported over 75,000 European citizens, who managed to return home from every corner of the world, thanks to the coordination and funding of the mechanism. In March, and while the pandemic was already spreading, rescEU created for the first time pan-European medical reserves, with protective equipment such as masks, essential machines such as respirators, and with the provision to integrate vaccines or treatments when available. Enough has been done, but we can certainly do a lot more together.  The pandemic has also highlighted weaknesses that we must immediately correct. Last February, President Michel proposed reducing the budget for the mechanism to EUR 1 billion for the period 2021-2027. But the events that followed showed how wrong his proposal was. For 2020 alone, the treaties forced the Commission to add an additional EUR 400 million to the mechanism.  Italy also first activated the mechanism, asking for help in early March. However, the material was delivered to her at the end of April, when the pandemic was already gradually receding. In 2017, following the fires in Portugal, President Juncker, effectively heralding the creation of the rescEU, called for a Europe that can effectively protect human life, not just send condolences to the families of the victims. Unfortunately, because of the Council's insistence at the time, the effort was incomplete. With the report we are debating today, the aim is to complete this work. We are substantially strengthening prevention by creating pan-European resilience targets for cross-border risks, linking them to national response plans. We are increasing funding to one hundred per cent for all instruments included in the rescEU, even for firefighting planes. We give the European Commission the right to buy instruments itself, when necessary, so that aid arrives on time, so that what happened in Italy, i.e. the two-month delay, does not happen again. Finally, we are tripling the budget of the mechanism for the next period, with an additional EUR 2 billion from the European Recovery Fund, exceeding a total of EUR 3 billion. We want the mechanism to be able to directly and effectively address not only a possible second wave of pandemic or forest fires, but also any other gray or black swan that occurs, threatening to change our lives in a dramatic and unexpected way.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, on behalf of my friend and colleague Janez Lenarčič, who can’t make it tonight, I am really pleased to discuss with you the report prepared by Mr Androulakis on the Commission’s proposal to amend the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. As Europe continues to struggle with the COVID—19 pandemic, we must recognise this as one of the worst health crises the continent has experienced in over 100 years. The statistics are harsh. Within the European Union alone, almost 4 million confirmed cases and over 210 000 deaths have been recorded to date. At the beginning of the crisis, unfortunately the response to requests for assistance was often too slow, or failed to materialise. The honourable Member of Parliament, Mr Androulakis, has already referred to this, and once again I have to say that the EU Member States were not in a position to provide assistance through the Union Civil Protection Mechanism from their own resources. 25 out of 52 requests to the Mechanism remained unanswered and 27 were answered only partially. The current system of civil protection relies on solidarity among Member States. This means that it depends largely on voluntary offers from Member States. This works very well in most types of emergencies. An example is the recent explosion in Lebanon, where more than a dozen Member States offered assistance through the Union Mechanism. But the limits of the current system were quickly reached during the early stages of the COVID—19 crisis, when virtually all EU Member States were affected at the same time. The European Council recognised these limitations in its joint statement of 26 March. It gave the Commission a clear task to propose a more ambitious Crisis Management System within the European Union. The voice of the European Parliament to strengthen the Union’s mechanism was equally strong, and the Commission has reacted. The revised proposal adopted in early June aims to strengthen European response capacities by expanding the scope of rescue, drawing lessons from the COVID—19 pandemic. It would make our system more flexible, faster and more comprehensive, and ultimately more effective in the case of large—scale complex emergencies. The Commission welcomes the report by the Committee on the Environment, which recognises the impact of strengthening the Mechanism’s response capability through direct procurement of specific items by the European Commission, so that we can better support the Member States in case of need. Second, strengthening the European Response Coordination Centre, serving as a hub for the national civil protection centres to help strengthen our coordination, and thirdly putting a strong focus on prevention and preparedness, including through the establishment of Union—wide resilience goals. These are key aspects of our proposal. We also have the opportunity now to put in place an ambitious budget to support this enhanced EU Civil Protection Mechanism. As you know, the Commission has proposed to allocate EUR 3.1 billion for Civil Protection over the next seven years. The COVID—19 pandemic has shown that nature rolls the dice. This is our wake—up call. The next large scale emergency will strike again. it is only a matter of time. The way we choose to act now will determine how prepared we will be in the future. I hope that the report prepared by Mr Androulakis will receive your wide support.

name: Niclas HERBST
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to thank the commissioner for her work and for the work she has You are right, and that is indeed an ambitious objective in budgetary terms, which you have set yourself. They have our support.  We have made some changes in the Committee on Budgets, but they do not affect the nature and nature of their proposal. This is a good proposal for which you have our support. It is also good that we finally have a programme here that contains real European added value and not just the distribution to the Member States – that is also to be welcomed. Two points are still important to me personally: that it is clear that we are not talking about duplication of structures or competence disputes, but that it is really a question of creating strategic assets where the Member States are not making progress. This will also contribute to visibility.  And that is my second point: it must never happen again that foreign powers are visible in a crisis and the European Union is not. This requires this ambitious approach, also from a budgetary point of view. You have our support.

name: Sunčana GLAVAK
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, to begin, I would like to express my regret that we are not able to speak Croatian today and that there is no Croatian interpretation available. From 2001 to 2019, the EU Civil Protection Mechanism was activated more than 330 times in response to emergencies, while since the start of the 2020 pandemic, only for repatriation flights and air bridges, the mechanism has been activated over 400 times. Extreme temperatures, forest fires, floods, storms, earthquakes and even diseases are part of our reality and we always need to be able to respond effectively. Taught by the experience of the coronavirus pandemic, I believe that we need to strengthen the three pillars of the Civil Protection Mechanism: prevention, preparedness and response. After the devastating earthquake that hit Zagreb on 22 March, seven European countries sent emergency aid to Croatia. Thanks, Slovenia, Italy, Hungary Lithuania, Austria, Montenegro and France. Croatia was also among the first countries to receive protective equipment through rescEU during the first wave of the pandemic. It is encouraging to see the cooperation of the Member States at work at key times when, as individuals and as a community, we face a threat to our security. I welcome the announced significant increase in funding for the Civil Protection Mechanism as this ensures the strengthening of the Union’s capacity and action in the field of health and civil protection. It is necessary to strengthen the Civil Protection Mechanism and rescEU and make them more flexible, faster and better coordinated with national civil protection bodies. Thanks all of you that are helping us.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: I wanted to point out that the lack of interpretation for some languages is obviously not due to any other reason than a technical problem of connection encountered between the plenary and the other room we use, because for the measures to distancing COVID-19, unfortunately our interpreters can no longer work in the booths and, of course, we absolutely care about their utmost safety in carrying out the very important function and the services are working hard to solve this problem in the shortest possible time.  So let us hope that this evening we will have the good news that can be resolved. This is a purely technical problem which does not depend on our will.

name: Milan BRGLEZ
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, due to technical problems with interpretation, I will speak in English. I welcome today’s discussion and the report of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) on the changes to the Union Civil Protection Mechanism. It goes without saying that these changes are timely and very necessary. Both the text of the report and the almost unanimous support of the members of the ENVI Committee show that Parliament univocally supports enhanced cooperation between the States as well as the strengthening of the Union Mechanism. In my first discussion in the European Parliament last September, I spoke about the importance of mechanisms such as the Crisis Management Coordination Centre and the European capacity reserve of the rescEU for crisis response. Such disasters and crises cannot be resolved without cooperation and relying solely on national capacities. Member States, especially smaller ones, cannot afford to maintain high preparedness and large reserves in times of crises. In many Member States, including Slovenia, protection against natural and other disasters is still strongly dependent on volunteers. Solidarity and volunteering are values that I, as a social democrat and human being, strongly support. I honestly thank and extend my gratitude to everyone who selflessly helps fellow people and the communities. But volunteers cannot, and must not, bear the burden of major global crises. One of the biggest disappointments in this crisis is still the uncoordinated – sometimes also very selfish – behaviour of the Member States. In this chaos, the European Commission, within its competences, has quickly responded in the framework of the crisis and civil protection mechanisms in the EU and worldwide. So, even greater coordination, together with increased jurisdiction in the fields of health, crisis response mechanisms and civil protection, joint acquisition and maintenance of a commitment and vaccine reserves are essential for preserving the lives and health of the people.

name: Nicolae ŞTEFĂNUȚĂ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Mr President, in the age of climate change, we must prepare now, in 2020, for the world of 2030, a world that doesn’t look simple at all. ‘Protection is not a principle, but an expedient’. This is what Benjamin Disraeli said. Right now, as I speak, all over the world and in Europe we have forest fires, extreme weather and climate events. It is 31 degrees today on 14 September in Brussels, and we saw over 30 degrees all over the Arctic Circle in March. It’s very clear that we need an improved European Union Civil Protection Mechanism, and we need it fast. The coronavirus has shown us the great need for an effective European disaster response. We can no longer afford a situation similar to when Italy came to this House and we had to show our empty pockets. We’ve seen how disinformation and populism rise on our clumsiness and our hesitations. European citizens are watching us and want to see that we’ve learned from this crisis, that we have gone through it and are going forward. Take a look at yesterday’s figures. The second wave of the pandemic in Europe is here. It’s happening now, right before your eyes. Two hundred thousand deaths – you said it, that is the greatest tragedy that Europe has suffered since the end of the Second World War. In the face of such crisis, we have the chance to strengthen the Civil Protection Mechanism through this week’s vote. Our group’s priority in Renew Europe is to ensure that the European Union has a flexible emergency response system, one that is centred on people and livelihoods. The Commission must be able to purchase more quickly and without depending on the will of one Member State or another. The Commission must be able to intervene in the case of fires, to repatriate essential workers, such as my fellow Romanian navigators who are stranded in different ports around the world, or to help in humanitarian situations, such as the one unrolling before our eyes in Moria. Let’s prove that we’ve learned from our lessons. Let’s act today for the Europe that our children want for their future!

name: Marco DREOSTO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the dramatic experience of the health emergency has made us understand how instruments such as European civil protection need to be strengthened. Indeed, it is not possible to forget how at the height of the crisis in Italy and, despite the ambassador's requests, no one – and I stress no country in the European Union – has responded positively to the request for help. The aid has actually arrived, but only in particular from small countries, such as Albania or, even from distant Cuba. This, ladies and gentlemen, can absolutely no longer happen. That is why the proposal by the rapporteur, Mr Androulakis, which seeks to strengthen this instrument, must, in our opinion, absolutely be shared and goes in the right direction.  I would also like to take this opportunity to thank Commissioner Lenarčič, who is not here this evening, and also his offices, of course, for the significant commitment and willingness he has always shown in answering my questions and missives. Despite the fact that the Commission has also made European civil protection available to strengthen monitoring at Italy's borders on the Balkan route, the Minister of the Interior of my country still does not ask for its use, effectively condemning the citizens of my region, Friuli Venezia Giulia, to suffer continuous waves of migration and then operating the border police forces without the appropriate means of protection.  Well, it seems strange to say by a loyalist, but in this case the European Commission has tried to meet the needs of my citizens more than the Italian Government which, unfortunately, has been totally and guiltily absent on the Balkan issue.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: for the GUE/NGL group. – Mr President, the Civil Protection Mechanism of the European Union, in its original form, has been designed to help Member States deal with natural disasters. RescEU capacity, a Pan-European reserve of aircraft and helicopters for firefighting, specialised medical equipment and other resources have been created. The pandemic has come and I am very glad that medical supplies, such as personal protective equipment or laboratory equipment, have also been included in rescEU capacities. The European Union Civil Protection Mechanism became one of the few instruments of solidarity during the pandemic. However, we can now make this mechanism much more efficient and faster. Experience with fires and pandemics has shown that the European Union and the Member States are not sufficiently prepared to respond to large-scale emergencies, which is unacceptable. Where cooperation makes sense, it should be encouraged. And when is it more necessary than when life is at stake? I'm glad we made a deal.

name: Stelios KYMPOUROPOULOS
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs on their contributions to the report. The overall objective of the EU Civil Protection Mechanism is to strengthen cooperation between the EU Member States and create a strong bond to face all disasters. The experience during the COVID-19 pandemic has shown that the Union and the Member States are not adequately prepared to respond to large-scale emergencies. We have witnessed two different European faces, the first of unconditional help with medical support and equipment offered between Member States, and the second, that is disappointing for our values and common future as a Union, in which some Member States closed their borders to EU citizens or temporarily detained medical and protective equipment just for themselves.  We cannot talk about solidarity or respect for the European citizens’ well-being when we allow some Member States to work unilaterally. We cannot talk about strong mechanisms created and functioning within the framework of our institutions when some of the Member States act for their own personal interest, with no transparency against other Member States, whatever their purpose is.  We are and should remain a strong, united union of countries fighting for the fundamental right for health in the 21st century to all the European citizens. We are elected to make sure that this will be preserved on its absolute ratio.

name: Aurelia BEIGNEUX
text: Mr President, you have a clear knack for turning gold into lead. Until now, the European Civil Protection Mechanism has been one of the few European policies to be unanimous. A symbol of solidarity among the European peoples, this arrangement was regularly touted even within our ranks. On several occasions it has helped Member States affected by disasters and this is one of the few occasions when the European Union acts as a mutualisation body and not as a retaliation body. While each country could operate the mechanism to deal with cases of force majeure, you now want to take control of it, on the grounds that the COVID-19 crisis requires a reorganization of the system. In fact, you are using COVID-19 to enable the Commission to get its hands on a small freedom that the Member States still had. Worse still, the Commission wants to sell the mechanism at a discount to third countries. Which? The vagueness is deliberately maintained, the proposal projecting itself far beyond the few nations of the European Economic Area. Yes to solidarity actions on behalf of the peoples of Europe and not to your confiscation!

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, I would like to thank the For a change, I'll talk about German. I would like to thank you for the overwhelming support and the unified view.  But Mrs Beigneux's last speech then leads me to clarify a few things. What we are discussing now is a necessary further development of the existing mechanism, which, as some have quite rightly said, was originally designed to respond to natural disasters, and natural disasters – thank God – have not occurred simultaneously throughout Europe, so that this subsidiarity mechanism has worked. I have seen this time and again in my various responsibilities as Commissioner over the last ten years. Now we are faced with a disaster that affects virtually all Member States, and therefore their ability to help others is limited.  We have seen on a modest scale how the situation has simply improved in some countries, for example by transferring patients who needed intensive treatment to other countries where different beds were still available. But this was all very limited, and we also known to have had problems deploying a certain number of devices. All this is to be addressed and eliminated appropriately by this new mechanism. There can be no question of the Member States being deprived of any competences here. On the contrary, it is only a question of us being better prepared for future crises on the basis of the lessons we learn from the current situation, and that is the only purpose of this. However, I would also like to join in the thanks expressed to my colleague, Mr Lenarsic, for his very intensive and committed work over the past few months.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, first of all I would like to thank President Juncker and Commissioner Christos Stylianides for doing everything in their power to create the rescEU. And, of course, Commissioner Lenarčič who continues to work, as well as my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, with whom we have had excellent cooperation. In the light of the proposals we are putting forward, all European citizens feel as safe in whatever Member State they live in. The Committee on the Environment has adopted the text by a large majority, and I believe that we will have similar results in plenary. We acted quickly and I believe that, despite the difficult working conditions due to COVID-19, we can be ready to start negotiations in the next three months from the Commission's presentation, and thus have all the legislation in the Council.  Unfortunately, there are also some who do not share the sense of urgency. The German Presidency considers that there is time. They see the necessary changes that we are proposing with scepticism. They seem not to understand the new challenges, perhaps because they have the ability to respond to them themselves. Let's put aside the introversion and look at the big picture. The Council and the Member States must rise to the occasion and come to the negotiating table with a comprehensive proposal and not by salamiising legislation by transferring the necessary institutional changes to the distant future.  Stiffness is a bad advisor. We need flexibility and, with a compass of solidarity, to find a compromise for the benefit of all peoples. The vision of a self-sufficient Europe is the supranational mechanisms that can guarantee solidarity beyond the strengths of each state, whether we are talking about the social state, the economy or security. The 140,000 of our fellow human beings who have left the corovirus are not just a number — they are our relatives, they are our friends, they are our neighbours; to me they are my good friend Manolis. So the best way to honour their memory is to ensure that next time the European Union is more prepared to defend human life.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
