name: Edina TÓTH
text: Writing. – The coronavirus epidemic, which has been raging for months, presents a major challenge for the whole world, with a number of problems that have not yet been detected. Since its creation, the Civil Protection Mechanism has provided assistance to disaster-stricken countries not only in Europe but throughout the world. The recent period has shown that, in a case such as this, the EU should, in addition to coordinated assistance, procure and directly assist Member States, since, following the outbreak of the coronavirus outbreak, Member States have been left to their own devices to improve their own situation by buying masks, tests, ventilators, medicines and other tools essential to combating the pandemic. Unfortunately, we had to admit that the current crisis management system has its limitations, and that the EU must respond more quickly and effectively in the event of major emergencies such as the coronavirus. That is why I consider the amendment on the EU Civil Protection Mechanism to be extremely important, which would provide RescEU with an even greater resource, thereby ensuring adequate preparedness.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: The next item is the report by Mr Beazley on beazley: Jutta Paulus, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EU) 2015/757 to take due account of the global system for collecting data on ship fuel consumption (COM(2019)0038 - C8-0043/2019 - 2019/0017(COD)) (A9-0144/2020).

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to present to you today my report on maritime emissions. Maritime transport is so far the only sector in which the 'polluter pays' principle does not apply. There is no priceing of greenhouse gases or emission reduction targets. Shipping is not explicitly mentioned in either the Kyoto Protocol or the Paris climate agreement, although emissions from the sector are expected to increase by fifty percent compared to 2018 to 2050. Maritime transport already emits 138 megatonnes of CO2 a year from European Union ports. That is 3.7% of climate-related emissions in the EU. That is as much as is being ejected throughout Belgium. We know this very well because the EU adopted the MRV Regulation in 2015; since 2018, all ships over 5000 gross registered tonnes – no matter who they own, under which flag they fly, for whom they are sailing – have to report their CO2 emissions when using EU ports. These reports are verified, reported, the public has transparent access to them. After the EU adopted this regulation, the international shipping organisation, the IMO, finally moved and set up its own system. Last year, the Commission put forward a proposal to bring the reporting systems into line, but unfortunately it has missed the opportunity to move from counting to reducing emissions. And we can still do so much statistics, so we don't save a single gram of CO2.  This House declared a climate emergency in November last year. We must live up to our responsibility for the planet and for future generations.  That is why we are proposing two essential additions to the Commission's proposal: firstly, maritime transport will be included in the ETS emissions trading scheme by January 2022. This will be the first time that an incentive has been created to reduce the CO2 emissions of ships. There is already a comprehensive impact assessment for this, and it shows that this would reduce emissions from the sector by more than twenty per cent.  Madam President von der Leyen and Vice-President Timmermans have repeatedly promised, as part of the Green Deal, that shipping will be included in the ETS. We are now presenting a proposal here that will not only generate own resources for the EU budget – and Mr Hahn should be particularly pleased about this – but will also create a fund for research and development of climate-friendly vessels and the financing of marine protected areas.  Secondly, we want ships to be forty per cent more efficient on average by 2030 compared to 2018/2019 – for which we have very valid data. In this way, this sector can play its part in helping to increase the climate targets by 2030, which we are currently negotiating in the Climate Act. If the volume of transport remains the same, this measure alone would fill ten per cent of the gap we have if we increase the climate targets by 2030.  We also want a few things, such as the extension of the coverage of greenhouse gas emissions to the extremely climate-damaging methane, which is increasingly being used in LNG vessels and where studies are already taking place showing that emissions of methane have increased massively from maritime transport. We call on the Commission to take measures to ensure that we have zero emissions in ports. This is about protecting the health of our citizens, who can no longer be expected to be polluted.  Honourable Members, new reports are coming every day about the effects of climate change: East Africa is sinking into rains, the west coast of the USA is burning, the Alpine glaciers are dwindling. I believe that we must shoulder our responsibilities and reduce emissions as quickly as possible in all areas.  I would like to take this opportunity to thank my colleagues once again for their good cooperation on this report.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, addressing shipping emissions remains a priority for the Commission. The EU system to monitor, report and verify these emissions is an important step to integrating emissions into EU climate policy; but it is just a first step, because we aim to come up with plans to reduce overall emissions in the maritime sector. The key goal of our reporting system is to collect robust and verified CO2 emissions data, to make those data publicly available, to stimulate the uptake of energy-efficient technologies and behaviours, and to inform our policymaking.  Since the entry into force of the data collection system of the International Maritime Organization (IMO) in 2019, all large ships calling at ports in the European Economic Area have to report their full consumption and other information under two systems: the European and the international one. In accordance with the Monitoring, Reporting and Verification (MRV) Regulation, the European Commission has now proposed to align, where appropriate, the EU MRV system with the IMO data collection system. The aim is to preserve the objectives of the current MRV Regulation by keeping its governance and ambition, while including technical adjustments to align the two regimes, simplifying compliance. The Commission proposal does not affect the main thrust of the European system, which is to maintain the robustness and transparency of our rules. The report of the Environment Committee before you has received the Commission’s full attention. As you know, some proposed amendments go significantly beyond the Commission’s proposal to align the European global data collection systems, namely the amendment to extend the European Emissions Trading System (ETS) to maritime transport and the amendment for large shipping companies to reduce their annual average CO2 emissions by at least 40% by 2030. While the European Commission fully agrees with the European Parliament that the shipping sector needs to duly contribute to the implementation of the Paris Agreement and must achieve the Union-wide climate neutrality objective, we don’t consider the review of the EU reporting rules to be the appropriate vehicle to include shipping in the ETS or to introduce operational component density requirements. There is also no impact assessment for these two elements. There is a difference of opinion on the instrument, but our political goals are shared. As you know, the Commission has already announced, as part of the European Green Deal, its intention to extend the ETS to maritime emissions, and the impact assessment is being prepared. Work on this is in full swing and the Commission will come forward with the relevant legislative proposals to reduce the climate impact of shipping activities.  Let me stress, the Commission will duly take into account the elements proposed by this Parliament when developing its initiatives under the European Green Deal. For these reasons – and as we are still awaiting the Council’s position on these elements – the Commission has to reserve its position on the amendments concerning the extension of the Emissions Trading System and the carbon density requirements for ships. Of course, the same applies to other amendments that were not in the original Commission proposal. The Commission looks forward to continuing discussions on other important aspects of its proposal. These include possible improvements to the scope of the regulation in terms of ship size, rules when there is a change of company, the reporting of cargo carried, and the review clause within the remit of the reporting system. Let me assure you that the Commission remains committed to reducing emissions in the maritime sector. Let me also assure you that the upcoming 2030 Climate Target Plan will show not only this commitment but also the ambition to get it done. We will work hand in hand with this Parliament on our pathway to climate neutrality in shipping and beyond.

name: Pernille WEISS
text: ppe group. – Everyone must participate in the work of making the EU CO2 neutral by 2050, including shipping, no doubt about the case! And what is now being proposed could actually result in a reduction of at least 40% by 2030.  Perhaps we could even have reached the higher level, but where we are now, we are already where we have taken some long strong nautical miles, respecting the fact that shipping is an international industry in which the European Union does not decide everything, but has an important role in dragging the entire planet's shipping into the right course for the climate of all of us.  The EU thus has an important first mover role for the planet's green transition. But the first movers, indeed it is also the companies in the EU shipping industry, which have been making great efforts for several years to decarbonise their activities. They have done so with the effective use of the MRV regulation's CO2 reporting system, which now needs to be revised to make it an even better tool.  That is why the EPP – and I above all – is pleased that we in the European Parliament this week are hopefully coming up with a good negotiating mandate for the forthcoming trialogue between us and the Council, a mandate that combines high ambitions with respect for those who draw the heaviest load. First movers in all the EU industries, which are also at the centre of the green transition, they are watching from the sidelines and must, of course, see that the European Parliament both recognises and continues to support that it always pays to do its best.  What we are not happy with – and therefore do not support in the EPP – is to use the specific case, a revision of the MRV regulation, to throw the entire EU transit into the CO2 quota system, the ETS, without a proper impact assessment and without an independent and thoroughly drafted legislative proposal. It is simply sloppy haste, which is neither good legislative practice nor serves the purpose that the EU really has the opportunity to emerge as the planet's carbon-reducing beacon. With these comments, I look forward to the vote on Wednesday and thank you for a cooperation so far both challenging – and, finally, fortunately also constructive – cooperation. Thanks!

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, Europe is going through this huge transition from our history as a coal and steel union to the climate neutrality union. Everyone needs to contribute in that transition and today the shipping sector is not part of it. They sail away and do their own thing. It’s not acceptable. We need to make sure that everyone is part of this transition if we are to deliver what it is our right to do, as politicians. We know that the shipping sector also has a very negative impact on the climate and it risks to have even more so in the future. It’s extremely worrying that it, in fact, has proceeded to raise its contribution to emissions between 50 or 250% to 2050, when we are supposed to be climate neutral. We in the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D) refuse to stand passive and therefore we are very happy that in this monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) system is a good piece of legislation for reporting emissions, but now we finally have an Emissions Trading System (ETS) proposed on the table and we believe this will be very important to take this sector under its, rightly, demand to contribute. We also demand that every ship will reduce its emissions by at least 40% by the year 2030.  It should not be free to destroy the future – not the climate, not the environment – and we know that the environment is also hit by this sector today; biodiversity, air quality, we need to do something about that. Therefore, we would like to have a fund for the sea to help the sector improve on all this and we would also like a big part of this fund to go towards helping the sector to transition. So this is a really clever proposal that we worked on together. I would like to say to the rapporteur and to all the shadow rapporteurs that I have been very honoured to work with you. I really think we have something good on the table.

name: Catherine CHABAUD
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, behind this technical subject the collection of data on CO2 emissions from maritime transport is in fact a major issue of the Green Pact for Europe, but also of the European recovery plan. Major in particular on two subjects. The first is the decarbonisation of the sector. For several years, the International Maritime Organization has been engaged in the ecological and energy transition of maritime transport, but at an insufficient pace in relation to the issues and in particular the expected increase, as has been said, of emissions of 50 to 250% by 2050. It is all the more important to send a strong signal to the Commission and, beyond that, to the International Maritime Organization. Indeed, in this first world market, which represents Europe, 90% of goods pass through the sea. I can attest to this: when you sail, especially in the English Channel, the procession of cargo ships is impressive! I welcome the fact that the text sets numerical emission reduction targets (40% by 2030) and I call on the Commission to set a reference year that takes into account the data collected, i.e. 2018. I also urge him not to forget the maritime sector in the recovery plan. Pan-European projects are emerging and will give a competitive advantage over the construction of green vessels. The second major issue is the inclusion of shipping in the carbon market. Major, because the fruit of this enlarged market will feed the own resources, essential to the European recovery plan. It is also important because the Ocean Fund we are proposing to create will not only support the decarbonisation of the sector, but also finance the restoration of marine and coastal ecosystems, which contribute massively to the absorption of carbon. Finally, this text is part of a global strategic vision for me that Europe must be built with the sea, our common good and our future.

name: Mick WALLACE
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety (ENVI) showed real ambition in voting for a radical expansion of the scope of the Commission’s proposal. We are proposing to include shipping in the EU Emissions Trading System (ETS), without further delay with this regulation. Market-based solutions for the climate crisis, such as ETS, have generally failed. However, in this instance we are proposing to frame shipping’s inclusion in the ETS with a binding regulatory target of 40% emission reductions per transport work by 2030. The rapporteur’s report is mainly concerned with emissions efficiency. Shipping emissions are directly related to global trade and consumption. Therefore, in order to reduce absolute greenhouse gas emissions from maritime transport, in addition to emissions per transport work, the EU must promote and pursue a global de-growth strategy rather than the new growth strategy proposed in the European Green Deal. In Amendment 71, I also propose to delete the exemption for warships. Militaries are massive polluters. The US military, for example, doesn’t just destroy the lives of more people and communities than anyone else, as Julian Assange has highlighted, they’re also one of the biggest polluters on the planet, and I see no good reason to exempt any warships.

name: Eleonora EVI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the forecasts for maritime transport are truly appalling: global emissions from the sector could increase by as much as 250 % if we do not act and, even more absurdly, until now this sector has been excluded from European commitments to reduce greenhouse gases.  That is why I would like to congratulate Mrs Paulus on her excellent work on this regulation, which goes beyond adapting European legislation to the IMO's obligations on the fuel consumption data collection system, but makes this Parliament's voice heard loud and clear and calls for a binding target of a 40% reduction in annual CO2 emissions from ships by 2030. However, it does not stop there, because maritime transport is not only bad for the climate but also pollutes the air we breathe, with its dangerous emissions of sulphur oxides, nitrogen oxides and particulates, putting public health at risk.  That is why I am pleased that it contains yet another reminder to the European Commission to work on extending the sulphur and nitrogen oxide emission control zones in all European seas, including the Mediterranean.

name: Peter LIESE
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Last Tuesday, I had the pleasure of attending a ministerial conference of transport ministers on green shipping. I was actually a bit frightened. Most ministers have only explained what is not possible and why shipping cannot easily reduce its emissions. However, if we want to achieve ambitious climate targets – and we want to do so, also in order to avoid dangerous tipping points in the climate system – then everyone must make a contribution. That is why I am glad that there is broad agreement here in this House that we are tackling shipping and that we want to include it in the emissions trading system. Above all, I would like to thank Pernille Weiss, shadow rapporteur for the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats, but also everyone else. However, we in the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats make it clear that we want proper legislation. We will see on Wednesday that an impact assessment is not always bad for the climate, and that is why we want an impact assessment here as well. The Commission should present careful analyses and then a proposal that also takes account of the 'polluter pays' principle and recognises intermediate consumption. Then, I believe, we will be on the right track together. However, the PPE-DE will in any case vote in favour of the report. We ask for our amendment 63 to be accepted. However, we want this Parliament to send out a clear signal: shipping must finally bear its responsibilities.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Madam President, today we are discussing the system of collecting data on greenhouse emissions produced by maritime transport and on its adaptation, which we must do, to the new international regulation of the IMO. But above all, today's debate serves us to shed light on a sector, the maritime transport sector, which is one of the very few that does not have a timetable and demanding legislation for its decarbonisation; where it also accounts for 2.3% of all global emissions. That is why today we are calling, inter alia, that we can urgently introduce this sector into the EU emissions trading scheme already in place and also set clear limits on access to our ports for the most polluting vessels. Why? Because, if we do not, we can compromise all climate targets and the Paris Agreements while undermining the efforts already being made by many other sectors in Europe.

name: Pierre KARLESKIND
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, 350 is the number of ships, cargo ships that pass almost under my windows in Brittany and join the procession that crosses the English Channel, as my colleague Catherine Chabaud said. When I see them or guess them a little off, I wonder what they emit. With this regulation and following the requirements of the International Maritime Organization, we will be able to find out. Beyond knowing, monitoring and monitoring, we will be able to take real action on the reduction of greenhouse gases in this sector, which is voluntary, with this ambitious target of a 40% reduction in 2030, as proposed by our fellow rapporteur. Beyond that , and I think that is the meaning of some elements of this report, we want to ensure that it does not achieve the competitiveness of our fleet. That tomorrow, among these 350 ships, there is still a significant share of European ships. That is why it is a good proposal.

name: Johannes Hahn
text: Member of the Commission. –  Madam President, thank you for this very rich debate. It’s inspiring to see that this Parliament remains committed to tackling emissions in the maritime sector. Together with you, the Commission wants to ensure that the maritime sector duly contributes to our climate objectives. The Commission has doubts that the European reporting rules for shipping emissions are the right place for some of your proposals, but the Commission does stress again that it will work vigorously on extending the EU ETS to cover maritime, as well as on other initiatives to reduce maritime emissions. We will duly assess the impact of such initiatives. Importantly, we will continue to take due account of the proposals in this Parliament for the European reporting rules for maritime emissions and the reform of European emission trading. The upcoming climate target plan for 2030 will show this ambition, and the Commission looks forward to continuing to work with you.

name: Jutta PAULUS
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Thank you for the very detailed and very lively debate. I would just like to comment briefly on a few things, because it may not have reached everywhere. Just as the MRV regulation already applies to all ships entering EU ports, no matter what flag they fly under, no matter who they belong to, no matter who they are sailing for, our proposals to extend this regulation now are, of course, coined to the entire scope, to the full scope of the MRV. In other words, there are no disadvantages for EU shipping companies or shipping companies or charterers, but it affects everyone equally. Those who do not want to enter the EU because they no longer want to sell goods here are, of course, free to do so. But I don't think that's going to happen anytime soon. I would like to clarify one more thing, because this is always confused. With the efficiency target, we are talking about the fact that by 2030, fleet emissions must be 40% below the fleet average – the average fleet today. In other words, the first movers, who have already done something, whose ships are already much more efficient, have only a much smaller way to go. In other words, their efforts are automatically rewarded because, of course, they have already made their investment, while everyone else has it ahead of them. This means that they already have a competitive advantage, because of course they also consume much less fuel.  As far as openness to technology is concerned, I would also like to say this briefly: if you do not want to make an investment, you can simply slow down. If you reduce the speed by 20%, you can save 40% of fuel. This means that you can also achieve this efficiency goal simply by driving slowly. My final point is that I've been on a lot of panels now. There are many possibilities, whether methanol, whether ammonia, they are actually just waiting for them to get a signal that the maritime sector will be held to account, because then such investments will also be worthwhile.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The amendments will be voted on on Tuesday 15 September 2020 and the final vote will take place on Wednesday 16 September 2020.  Written declarations (Article 171)

name: Magdalena ADAMOWICZ
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – Integrating maritime transport into the EU Greenhouse Gas Emission Trading System (EU ETS), reducing CO2 emissions from ships by 40% by 2030, or finally maximal reducing greenhouse gas emissions when ships stop at port are extremely ambitious tasks facing European shipping today.  At the same time, it is a necessary contribution by the maritime sector to reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the European economy, which aims to achieve full climate neutrality for Europe by 2050. However, it should be borne in mind that, in order for these solutions to be implemented, a comprehensive assessment of the impact of the proposed regulations on issues such as the competitiveness of European maritime transport or employment in the maritime sector is needed.  Equally important is the availability of advanced technologies to effectively reduce emissions. At present, much is being said, for example, about alternative fuels for ships, m.in. the use of hydrogen to power ships, but these are not yet widely used solutions. Without adequate support for investment in innovative technologies and infrastructure, the gradual decarbonisation of maritime transport will not be possible.

name: Benoît LUTGEN
text: In writing. Ladies and gentlemen, I invite you to support this text to the end because it is essential that all sectors of the economy, including the maritime sector, contribute and participate today in the joint effort to complete the transition to achieve the goal of climate neutrality in the European Union in 2050.  Indeed, I would remind you that at present, shipping is the only sector that is not expressly targeted by a target of reducing CO2 emissions or specific mitigation measures. However, if nothing changes, global emissions from the maritime sector will be expected to increase by 50% to 250 by 2050.  I therefore invite you to vote: for the inclusion of the maritime sector in the CO2 Emissions Trading Scheme (ETS); for the introduction of energy efficiency standards for ships at EU level; for regulation of access to EU ports for the most polluting vessels and the possibility of forcing moored vessels to use shore power. I would also point out that an Oceans Fund should be created from the revenues created. Thank you

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the report by Hannah Neumann, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on arms exports: implementing Common Position 2008/944/CFSP (2020/2003(INI)) (A9-0137/2020).

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, arms are not like any other export goods, because far too often they are used to suppress opposition or to kill civilians. And that is why it’s so important that once a year we discuss EU arms exports in this Parliament, and that’s also why it’s so important that we use this report to improve our way to control where arms end up in this world. And that’s why I decided to use my report to focus on two things: on transparency and on convergence. In our report we all together reached quite a lot. For example, we are calling on the European External Action Service to actually translate these 500 pages of numbers and columns into an online-searchable database so that public oversight is actually possible. We also ask the European External Action Service to build up a joint EU-level end-user control, rather than forcing 27 Member States to do like a semi-functional system, and we have a number of other suggestions on which we reached broad consensus in our negotiations. And I think we can be very proud, because they help us to better scrutinise and regulate EU arms exports. But as proud as we all can be, this doesn’t solve the main problem, and the main problem is that we have one common position on arms export of the EU, but we have 27 national interpretations, 27 export systems, and an increasing divergence in actual exports of Member States. And the more we work together in arms production, the more this will be a problem ˗ the more this will be a problem for democratic control and oversight, because if Member States produce arms together, who actually decides over the exports? Is it the Member State that puts in the most parts? Is it the Member State that puts in the last screw? Can one block all? Do you need to vouch your rights for democratic control before you can join? This is not very clear. And the conflict between France and Germany last year over arms exports to Saudi Arabia clearly showed how easily this can create tensions. But this divergence is also a problem for a common EU foreign and security policy. We were also happy about the good results of the Berlin Conference earlier this year. We even set up an EU mission in the Mediterranean to enforce the arms embargo against Libya, and this very same mission reported a violation of the arms embargo by Turkey and the UAE, yet EU Member States still supply Turkey, the UAE and all the other countries breaking this arms embargo with weapons, and some of these weapons end up with Sarraj, others end up with Haftar, all fuelling the violence. And Mr Borrell, I really wouldn’t want to be in your shoes trying to build a consistent EU foreign policy on that mess. And then, my dear colleagues from EPP, there’s the arms industry: the arms industry that already today complains that all these national regulations make cooperation super difficult, that arms export decisions are not reliable and that they cannot do business that way. And to be frank, I totally get their point. And dear colleagues, all these examples clearly show that if we want to do joint arms production, we need to do joint arms export control as one EU. What I really don’t understand is why the Commission, the Member States and parts of this Parliament are pushing so much for an internal defence market for joint arms production ˗ even putting money into it ˗ and at the same time, the very same people refuse to even discuss an EU-level involvement in democratic oversight and export control and thereby undermine what they want to reach: a European defence union and strategic autonomy of the European Union. I want to thank all my shadows for the very fierce and fair debates we had in the negotiations. We’ve reached a lot, but on this point we didn’t reach consensus, and that’s why I decided to bring it to the parliamentary debate today. I’m very much looking forward to the discussion.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Ms Neumann and Members who have contributed to this important resolution on European arms exports. I think it includes many useful suggestions that will help me to deal with a difficult subject like this in a more convergent, transparent and responsible way.  You are right that decisions on arms exports receive great attention and are politically sensitive because indeed trade in arms may potentially carry the risk of serious breaches for human rights, humanitarian law and regional stability, and most of the time the three things together. A strict implementation by Member States of the agreed common positions on arms exports is therefore essential to uphold the European Union’s values and its strategic objective. As you state in your report, this is also crucial for our credibility as a geopolitical player. A high level of convergence with regard to its full application will indeed more effectively ensure respect for human rights and international law by all parties involved. I think we can say that we, the European Union, are moving fast in the field of defence. The European Defence Fund and the European Peace Facility will serve to strengthen internal collaboration on defence matters to make the European Union a more capable security provider at the global level. Our defence industries will become ever more closely intertwined. They will strengthen our strategic autonomy and the protection of our citizens, fostering innovation and saving cost. All that is right, but, at the same time, in this context, further convergence of arms export policies becomes still more important.  As mentioned in your motion for a resolution, maintaining a vibrant and innovative defence industry in the European Union is a key component of our strategic autonomy and our European defence. It serves to ensure our capabilities and reduce dependency, while the defence industry is also a major source of technological innovation. I will give you some examples. In 2018, it generated more than EUR 100 billion in revenue and supported more than 400 000 jobs in Europe – 400 000 jobs! To ensure a thriving defence industry, exports are essential, but of course the defence industry is different from other industrial sectors and deserves special consideration, taking into account its obvious links to national and international security, human rights and humanitarian values. That’s why the European Union Member States have also exported control rules in place for military equipment since 2008. Under the common position on arms export, Member States assess arms export license applications against a number of criteria established to ensure our strategic interests and also our values. A review of this text was finalised last year. The Council agreed that the common position will serve this purpose but introduce some changes to bring the text into line with the adopted Arms Trade Treaty and other recent developments. In your own statement on the common position on arms export control, you stress three key objectives: the need for increased control, convergency and transparency. First, your support for an increase control. Let me start by saying that I am grateful the report welcomes operations within these objectives to implement a United Nations arms embargo on Libya. This is a concrete example of what the European Union does to prevent arms ending up in the wrong hands. Further, as a global actor, the EU supports outreach activities to assist countries in the European neighbourhood and beyond in setting up arms export control mechanisms and implementing the Arms Trade Treaty.  Second, on transparency, European Union Member States are already among the most transparent countries, including in arms exports. Still, in order to increase the possibility to further scrutinise accountability, I am glad to say that this year the European External Action Service will launch a public, searchable database on its website to allow all stakeholders to consult and analyse Member States’ arms exports in a user-friendly way. So everybody will be able to know what the Member States’ arms exports are about – everybody will be able to find out whatever data they want to know about it.   Third, and lastly, increased convergence. Member States are holding regular exchanges to share information on policies, denial of licences and possible measures. As a concrete result, a new initiative has been launched and the working party on arms exports is currently preparing a Council decision to set rules on end-user certificates for the export of small arms and light weapons and their ammunition.  Let me conclude by anticipating that the next annual European Union arms export report on 2019 will become available shortly, probably in October, two months earlier than in previous years, and it will bring a lot of precious information about these developments. I would like to thank you for your attention. I am looking forward to hearing your points or views.

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Madam President, thank you to the rapporteur and to all the colleagues who have been involved in this difficult text. Difficult, because this subject mixes industrial, legal and moral considerations, it was well understood in the introductory presentation, on a sensitive subject. And it is also difficult because it must be admitted that this Parliament has no prerogatives on the subject. I understand that this is distressing many colleagues who would like to be able to take control of arms exports, but it is not, it is a national prerogative. Where I disagree with what was said in the introduction to this debate is that just because this European Parliament does not have control over a subject does not mean that there is no such thing as democratic control. Democratic control exists in our national parliaments on this very specific subject of arms export controls. This is one of the strong enough reservations that my group has about this report, namely that these national prerogatives should not lead to systematic suspicion on the part of our Parliament. The other point of reservation concerns a point addressed by the rapporteur, which is the production of armaments at European level. However, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union as such does not produce armaments and the instruments you are talking about, the European Defence Fund for example, are still virtual instruments. I would remind you that this fund does not have a budget at this time, nor the same regulation of application, and that when it comes into force, it is likely to be $1 billion a year. Everyone knows that weapons programs are much broader than that. So we'll talk about it in due course. When these Genuinely European, European weapons programmes are in place, we may be able to talk about the modalities of control. For now, it's virtual. So I understand the impatience of some colleagues to make this chamber play a more active role, but we are not there yet. That is why my group has strong reservations about the very ideological motivations of this report, even if we will support everything that goes in the direction of convergence, transparency and good information.

name: Joachim SCHUSTER
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which she has done so. I, too, would like to thank the rapporteur for the work that is involved in the draft. I believe that there are many reasons for the EU to come closer together in terms of foreign and security policy.  And one element of greater foreign and security sovereignty is certainly increased cooperation on arms production. European cooperation eliminates the need for costly duplication of structures and can thus also save public funds, which we urgently need for the peaceful resolution of conflicts and for the elimination of causes of conflict.  But increased arms cooperation, whether within the EU or between individual Member States, also requires European arms export control, especially in view of the fact that the EU states together are the second largest arms exporter in the world behind the US. After all, strict arms export control is undoubtedly linked to greater European cooperation and can no longer be regarded merely as a national matter.  As early as 2008, the EU adopted criteria to be examined and respected by Member States in the case of arms exports. However, the criteria are still not always respected. This is true even with arms exports to countries participating in the wars in Yemen and Libya.  Arms exports sometimes allow for or prolong military conflicts. They often make it possible to break international law. In other words, it is not enough just to express noble intentions and to call on Member States without consequences to act in accordance with the common criteria. We also need a sanction mechanism in case individual Member States ignore the agreed common criteria, because European cooperation also requires European enforcement.  And another thing that has just been added: we need an immediate halt to all arms exports to Turkey. Turkey is threatening us with war. It would be absurd if we also supply Turkey with the weapons to kill EU citizens. I would therefore ask you to support the S&D Group's amendment.

name: Klemen GROŠELJ
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the report assesses the implementation of the Common Position on arms export and related technologies, and evaluates the progress that the EU, and especially Member States, have made so far.  This report is a political compromise that reflects the complex nature of the topic. It spans from the basic right of every state to self-defence, enshrined in the UN Charter, to the eternal aspiration of human kind for universal peace and security. Arms export and related technologies are inevitably subject to fierce ideological discussion.  The report reflects the steps forward made by Member States towards respecting the EU Common Position on arms export, and more and more Member States are following the Common Position and its eight criteria on arms export and related technologies. Although greater progress is needed, it is important to recognise all efforts made in this report. And we must bear in mind that arms export is still a Member State competence, which is why the progress made in respecting the Common Position is even more important. The future development of the Union and of the international environment will require greater convergence among Member States on arms export. A growing number of joint development programmes in the field of defence production will expose the need for a common approach to arms export among Member States as well as at EU-level. Defence production is destined to become more European and arms export control mechanisms will need to reflect this new reality. This new reality, in turn, will need to be reflected in EU legislation as well.  But despite great ambitions, we are not yet at that point. This is why we are not in favour of an ad hoc sanction mechanism in this field and prefer a future European solution instead. This can be achieved through a gradual approach, in parallel with the development and strengthening of the common security and defence policy. Regardless of all differences, the report reiterates that the Common Position and its necessary mechanisms must ensure that exported arms and related technologies are not used in a wrong way and above all, are not in the possession of the wrong actors. We need to ensure that exported arms and technologies are not used for violating human rights and basic values.

name: Jérôme RIVIÈRE
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, since the beginning of this mandate, certain groups, under the benevolent gaze of the Commission, have shown a mad desire to interfere in a regal domain par excellence, which belongs only to the nations, that of defence. After trying to divert funds and lose them in a European Defence Fund, which would support arms programmes without an operational need for staff to validate them, they are trying with this text to regulate arms exports. All the pretexts are good to wrest from the states the last parts of their sovereignty. What blindness! More than ever, the world is uncertain. In the Mediterranean, this historic, economic and cultural space, tensions are erupting that will shape our future. The European Union demonstrates its inability to act; worse, it marks sharp differences between a continental bloc, led by Germany, and the countries of the South. Threatened by Turkey, it is France which, by its sovereign policy of exporting armaments, in the autonomous areas of its army and navy, delivers to Greece in record time the Rafale it needs. Each time, the news demonstrates the absurdity of these projects. We will continue to oppose this centralizing, reductive and weakening vision of moving peoples away from nations and their parliaments, the only legitimate centres of political decision-making.

name: Salima YENBOU
text: on behalf of the Greens/FTA group. Mr President, Mr Borrell, tell me how the European Union can still be credible in its speeches on human rights, if its own Member States continue to export weapons used against people to war zones, sometimes under security pretexts, often in reality for economic purposes. How can we accept that, in my country and elsewhere, a defence minister can hide behind the lack of transparency to deny that French weapons are involved in the perpetuation of war crimes, particularly in Yemen? The current situation is unacceptable. We expect the von der Leyen Commission and the German Presidency to have a real strategy to ensure that this stops. I would remind you that seven of the world's top ten arms exporters are European. This is another reason to demand that no European weapons be used against civilians anywhere in the world. Full transparency must be put in place. The European Union must no longer turn a blind eye to these scandals. Finally, let us be consistent with our words to our actions.

name: Özlem DEMIREL
text: Mr President, I would like to like to sanendour sto -- on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Madam President, Mr Borrell, I would like to thank mr Borrell for his work on The EU Nobel Peace Prize laureate not only allows inhumane conditions in Moria, no, arms exports even create causes of flight.  This policy is in no way to be relativised or excused. Examples would be: Yemen, a brutal war, with weapons made in the EU. Syria, jihadists on leopard tanks, an invading in violation of international law, with weapons made in the EU. Eastern Mediterranean, an escalation spiral. Greece gets weapons from France, Turkey weapons from Germany. What does that mean? Weapons made in the EU again!  Ladies and gentlemen, the EU is vice-world champion in arms exports. The coffers of the arms companies are ringing. And I wonder, what is actually prohibited with the common position, which prohibits arms exports to crisis areas – is that of any interest here at all? I believe that we need sanctions for these abuses, because the common position must be respected. And you too have a duty to do so, Mr Borrell!

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Dear High Representative, over the last four years, the 28, now 27 EU Member States, have been the world's second largest supplier of military equipment with 26% of total exports. Important figures which, on the one hand, demonstrate the competitiveness of the industrial sector, and on the other hand call into question the guiding instrument with regard to the granting of export licences, that legally binding common position, but often, indeed almost always, not respected, because there are no repercussions for infringements. I strongly believe that this process must be accompanied by as many community control instruments that go beyond the common position.  We have done a great deal for defence, creating the new European Defence Fund and talking about military mobility, but this must go hand in hand with the introduction of a common export regime, including a supervisory body and a robust sanctions mechanism for all breaching governments. This must be done in order to be credible if we really want to be the global champion of peace and diplomacy that we often declare.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, today we are discussing the implementation of the Council's common position on arms exports to third countries. If we want to be honest with ourselves, this common position remains a wish list. A typical example is Turkey: Only in the last two years have we had illegal invasions of Syria and an illegal invasion of Iraq, the failure to respect the decision to impose an arms embargo on Libya — in which Turkey even threatened a frigate acting as part of Operation Peace — violations of the sovereign rights of Greece and Cyprus, and of course a threat of war — the so-called 'casus belli' dating back to 1995. Nevertheless, and while the Council has already called since last October for the strict application of the common position towards Turkey, nothing has changed. That is why we are asking you, in an amendment we have tabled, to take the initiative to stop European arms exports to Turkey. European weapons cannot be used to threaten two of our Member States. In fact, what you need to do is the minimum sign of solidarity, and it must be done immediately.

name: Clara PONSATÍ OBIOLS
text: – Madam President, this Parliament has repeatedly called for arms exports to Saudi Arabia to stop. But these calls are ignored. Spain has a long tradition of arms deals with Saudi Arabia and the government of Mr Sánchez, keeping up with this tradition, has authorised sales for about 400 million in 2019. Deals with the Saudis are the family business of the Spanish royals, a business that operates under the complacent watch of all Spanish governments since 1975. King Juan Carlos’s affairs with his Saudi buddies are now finally under investigation, but not in Spain – in Switzerland. What are the Spanish authorities doing about this? Nothing. They not only refused to investigate, they participated in the cover-up. They sent the King to Abu Dhabi to hide away from Swiss justice and they keep on selling weapons to the Saudis. This must stop. Corrupt interest in Member States cannot take precedence over our moral obligations.

name: Pierfrancesco MAJORINO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the trade in and export of arms must be governed not only by industrial logic but first and foremost by European foreign policy strategies and, in this context, by strict respect for human rights and our fundamental values.  That is why we must improve transparency and parliamentary control and establish a mechanism of sanctions that guarantee absolute compliance with the rules.  The situation is really very worrying: we have to tell ourselves. Let us think of the fact that several Member States continue to export to Egypt weapons and instruments used for internal repression, in a country where the absence of human and democratic rights is confirmed, despite a decision of the European Council of 2013, which was clearly ignored. Or business – let us think about this too – always linked to the arms industry, which too many do in Turkey, or what is happening in Libya. Control over arms sales is certainly not the solution to all problems, but it is an essential element in sending out clear and strong political signals that are so much needed.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, I understand the criticism. I heard some interesting points for sure. Let me summarise some of your points. First, criticism on exports from Member States to sensitive destinations. Yemen, Saudi Arabia and Turkey have been mentioned, but as one of the members that participated in the debate rightly remembered, decisions when issuing export licences are taken at the national level. So there is very little we can do from the European Commission. This is something that is taken at the national level, but we can call for more conversions in arms export policies as the Member States implement it. And on that, I agree completely. Here we are together, because we think that we can behave together in accordance with general rules which reflect our values. So it’s a Member State competence, but we need more convergence on the way each Member State implements these competences. There are also calls for arms embargoes for specific destinations. I could also agree, but an arms embargo to a specific destination requires unanimity in the Council. You should be aware of that, and you know how difficult it is to get unanimity today. But for sure, we can try to agree an arms embargo, but then you have to implement them and experience shows how difficult it is to do so, as we tried to do with the Irini operation in Libya. First unanimity, and second the willingness to really implement the decision. Military weapons have an indispensable role in the preservation of security, freedom and peace, provided that they are used in accordance with international law, human rights law and international humanitarian law. You cannot pretend to have security, and to protect freedom and peace, without having military resources. But you have to use them according to the law, and weapons of war are, by definition, capable of inflicting death and destruction. This ambivalence means that governments that export the weapons must ensure that they are traded and used in a responsible and accountable way, and prevent their diversion to terrorists, criminals and other unauthorised users. This must remain our ambition: to control the use of these weapons in order that they are not being misused. But by definition weapons inflict death and destruction, and our role is to try to be sure that they are used in accordance with the rules of war, and with the rules that protect human rights. Accountability for arms export decisions can only take place when authorities are transparent, and the European Union does all it can to ensure that utmost transparency is being upheld. This enables national parliaments, civil society and also the European Parliament to hold informed debate, and the Council and the Parliament clearly agree that the strengthening of the European defence technologies and industrial base should be accompanied by closer cooperation and conversions in the control of exports of military technology and equipment.  I will continue working in the process of increased convergence, and promoting more transparency in arms exports in the framework of the competences of the Commission and of the High Representative.

name: Hannah NEUMANN
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we reached a lot with this report and I would be very happy if we could confirm our many forward-looking proposals in the final version on Wednesday. But let’s not stop halfway. If we want the EU to play a role in this world in chaos, and if we want to build a true European defence union, we need to join in arms production, but we also need to join in oversight and arms export control. Et je comprends bien que ce sujet est une prérogative nationale, oui, but there is one thing that this European project has taught us: no one is going to come, Mr Borrell, and give this European Union and this Commission any competences all by themselves, and no one is going to come and offer this Parliament any rights for scrutiny, oversight or control. If we do not claim it and fight for it, it’s not going to happen.  And that’s why I call on all pro-European parties in this House – and I deliberately include PPE and Renew in this one – to vote tomorrow for Amendment 19; to vote for Amendment 19 that calls on the Member States and Commission to translate the Common Position on EU arms export, the Common Position that was reaffirmed by all 27 Member States one year ago, to transfer this Common Position into EU law. And to do it, to finish what we started, and make sure that the European Union can really control where EU arms, arms produced inside the EU, end up in this world in chaos.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The amendments will be voted on on Tuesday 15 September 2020 and the final vote will take place on Wednesday 16 September 2020.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: The next item is the report by Sven Mixer, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the implementation of the EU Association Agreement with Georgia (2019/2200(INI)) (A9-0136/2020).

name: Kati PIRI
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, it is the first time in this Parliament that I address you on behalf of a colleague, and not on behalf of myself: the rapporteur, Sven Mikser, who unfortunately couldn’t be here today. So allow me to give you his statement. As we are discussing a report focusing on the implementation of the Association Agreement between the EU and Georgia, I would like to recall that the Association Agreement is a comprehensive framework that covers a wide range of policy areas from political dialogue, rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, all the way to economic and trade relations. The report points out that enhanced cooperation and EU assistance to Georgia are based on the more-for-more principle and are conditional on continued reform processes across all policy areas. Georgia has undertaken ambitious reforms and achieved a lot. It deserves to be underscored that Georgia’s European aspirations enjoy broad support among almost all the political parties as well as among the Georgian people. The report also recalls that the EU-Georgia Association Agreement and ECFTA aims to gradually integrate the country with the EU single market and calls on the Commission to be more vocal in promoting and advancing this goal. Political life in Georgia, as we all know, is lively and dynamic. A worrying trend is the increased polarisation of the political scene. This report underscores the need to de-escalate the political discourse and continue reforms in order to guarantee media freedom and independence of the judiciary. Recently, Georgia has experienced a period of tensions between the government and the political opposition over changes to the electoral system. At the end of June the Georgian parliament passed a constitutional amendment that is designed to provide for more proportional representation and, hopefully, for more pluralistic political discourse after the parliamentary elections in 2020. With those elections approaching, the report emphasises the need to uphold and protect media freedom and guarantee equal access to the media for all political parties during this important election campaign. The elections will take place on 31 October, and I believe that if the COVID-19 situation allows for it, the European Parliament should also dispatch an election observation mission to Georgia. The report commends Georgia’s internationally-acclaimed response to the COVID-19 outbreak, and I would also like to highlight the exemplary cooperation between the EU and Georgia in responding to this crisis. And while assessing the progress Georgia has made, we cannot forget that one fifth of the territory of the country continues to be occupied. Hundreds of thousands of people are unable to return to their homes or face restrictions to their fundamental rights and freedom. And in addition, Georgia continues to be a target of Russian hybrid activities. The report strongly condemns the ongoing provocations and the borderisation activities that continue along the administrative boundary line. Finally, the report received the almost unanimous support of the Foreign Affairs Committee in this House, and the rapporteur, Sven Mikser, would like to thank all the political parties and the Groups who expressed their support to the legitimate aspirations of the Georgian people as well as to the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Georgia.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as you know very well, Georgia is a very close partner in our neighbourhood and subscribes to an ambitious Association Agreement with a deep and comprehensive free-trade area underpinned by common values, shared ownership and responsibility. Our relations have been maturing from the human rights agenda to connectivity, security, cooperation and academic exchanges under Erasmus+. Our norms on standards are gradually aligning, making real improvements in the lives of Georgian citizens.  We are looking forward to continuing to cooperate with Georgia, to agree joint priorities in an Association Agenda for post-2020, strengthening our cooperation, for instance to fight abuses in the visa-free regime, and I am also confident that our Eastern Partnership in March 2020 will devise a compelling vision for our multilateral relations. Our solidarity to support Georgia in mitigating the socio-economic consequences of COVID-19 is steadfast. I think more than EUR 180 million in bilateral funds and EUR 150 million in macro-financial assistance remains conditional on progress made. Let me have a look at the domestic challenges and opportunities of this country, and let me make reference to three important issues: the electoral context; the justice reform; and the conflicts. This is a crucial month ahead of the October parliamentary elections in Georgia. In March, the political parties reached a historic agreement, co-facilitated by the European Union delegation. It created a new electoral system more conducive to inclusive gradual and transparent elections. And now we expect effective implementation of these laws and respect for the highest democratic standards. In the justice sector it is important for the Georgian parliament to revisit the selection procedure for Supreme Court judges, which undermines a transparent, genuine, merit-based nomination process, as you mentioned in the report. It is critical to uphold the highest standards of ethics and integrity in the judiciary.  Finally, let me also reaffirm our unwavering commitment to Georgia’s sovereignty and territorial integrity within its internationally recognised borders. I agree with you that the continuing borderisation is completely unacceptable, since we have seen a deterioration of security along the administrative boundary line with the breakaway region of South Ossetia, such as in the Chorchana-Tsnelisi area. I am also very concerned about the continuous closure of crossing points, complicating medical treatment, contacts and access to livelihood. We are constantly reiterating our concerns to Russia in bilateral and multilateral fora and we will continue doing so on behalf of the stability of Georgia that deserves peaceful borders with all its neighbours. Thank you for your attention. I’m looking forward to our discussion.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, I would like to thank you for your support. I congratulate my rapporteur colleague on a balanced report, which I hope will receive broad support in the vote. Georgia is on track, committed to implementing the Association Agreement and the DCFTA, and has made efforts for democracy, fundamental human and liberties and good governance. In order to resolve domestic political tensions, a Memorandum of Understanding was reached on 8 March, which resulted in the amendment of the constitution and the electoral law according to international recommendations, so that the parliamentary elections in October will take place on the basis of the new principles. This is a milestone in the normalization of Georgia's domestic political environment, which we are all looking forward to, and we hope to see fair and fair elections. Georgian society has chosen Europe, so we must support it in this. We must mutually exploit the potential of the Association Agreement in order to deepen economic and trade cooperation. A positive approach, a more-for-more principle, and georgia's support in implementing the necessary reforms are important. It is important to help young people to participate as much as possible in EU mobility programmes and to provide quality learning opportunities. I would like to highlight Georgia's effective defences during the Covid epidemic, which is exemplary. Finally, I would like to stress that we must stand up for georgia's sovereignty and territorial integrity and say that we support its Euro-Atlantic and NATO integration efforts. Thank you.

name: Marina KALJURAND
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, to start with, I would also like to thank my good colleague Sven Mikser for this timely and well-balanced report. It is encouraging to see that popular support for the EU remains at a record high in Georgia. This also means the Georgian people deserve our solidarity. Therefore, as the co-chair of the EU-Georgia Parliamentary Association Committee, I would like to reiterate our full and unwavering support to Georgia’s sovereignty and territorial integrity.  The report on the implementation of the association agreement is an excellent framework to evaluate Georgia’s progress and talk openly about challenges. I welcome the recent electoral reform in line with the recommendations of the Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights (ODIHR) and hope that it will contribute to ease the polarisation in Georgia’s political and media landscape. I would also like to recognise the promotion of women’s representation. I urge all political parties, especially and including the opposition, to do their utmost to guarantee peaceful, fair and free elections on 21 October. These elections will be crucial in determining Georgia’s future for years to come.  Georgia has an impressive reform record. Of course, further approximation is still needed in some areas like environmental protection and the fight against discrimination of vulnerable groups. It is also true that Georgia is a young democracy where the rule of law must be further consolidated.  To conclude, I would like to congratulate the Georgian authorities for handling the COVID-19 crisis in an exemplary manner.

name: Urmas PAET
text: on behalf of the Renew Group. – Madam President, the upcoming parliamentary elections in Georgia on 31 October are a possibility for Georgia to demonstrate to its people that it is set and ready to be a stable democratic country.  The agreement reached by the political parties earlier this year on electoral reforms is the right step and must be fully implemented in order to be able to move forward and to overcome the political polarisation that has long been hampering progress in Georgia. The Georgian authorities should refrain from pursuing any politically motivated judicial cases and harassing opposition politicians. It is also imperative to guarantee media freedom, editorial independence and to take steps to prevent disinformation campaigns. Also, the people must be guaranteed freedom of thought and assembly. There are still many areas that need to be improved, like consolidating the rule of law, the fight against corruption and strengthening human rights and fundamental freedoms. It has been 12 years since the beginning of the recent conflict between Russia and Georgia. Unfortunately the conflict is still there. The ongoing illegal borderisation along the dividing lines damages the situation, prolongs the conflict and destabilises the whole region. In these especially fragile times of the COVID-19 pandemic, it is unacceptable that the de—facto South Ossetian authorities have repeatedly denied emergency medical evacuations and incoming humanitarian aid.  We have the obligation to not forget this conflict, but to continue supporting Georgia’s independence, sovereignty and territorial integrity within its internationally recognised borders.

name: Thierry MARIANI
text: on behalf of the ID Group. - Mr President, Georgia's recent history has led to calls for a balanced and prudent policy towards Tbilisi. I remember the astonishment of the international community, following the terrible consequences for Georgia of the 2008 defeat, after the adventures of Mr. Mikheil Saakashvili, who then left the country to join Ukraine. I doubt that we have learned the painful lesson of this experience, because the European Union is no longer seeking to improve its relations with the members of the Eastern Partnership, but to give them good or bad points of Atlanticism. The Serbian government recently announced that it was halting the joint military exercise "Slavic Brotherhood" with Russia and Belarus, due to pressure from the European Union. At the same time, the military exercise "Noble Partner" opened in Georgia under the aegis of NATO and brought together 2,800 soldiers with the participation of the French army. When are we finally going to emancipate ourselves from American tutelage? Are we going to continue to entrust the fate of a part of our continent to an organization that is rightly described as brain dead and whose action sometimes boils down to multiplying provocations against Russia in support of the end of the United States?

name: Viola VON CRAMON-TAUBADEL
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. Since we have seen many challenges in Georgia throughout the past year, it was good to see that cooperation among the international friends of Georgia worked. With all our and your support, the major political parties struck a deal on a new electoral system for the upcoming elections. These elections are crucial to Georgia’s democratic path. Georgia also demonstrated significant success in fighting COVID-19. In this struggle, the EU supported Georgia with assistance worth some EUR 100 million. Despite being the leader in the region, some problems still have to be overcome. Internally, the shadow rule of billionaire Ivanishvili threatens democracy. Externally Russia’s continuous hybrid war threatens the country’s sovereignty through military occupation, creeping annexation and cyberattacks. We need to support Georgia’s sovereignty, territorial integrity and its European future. A level playing field should be guaranteed for all political actors, while the judicial system should become more transparent.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent report. Despite obstacles and difficulties, Georgia is maintaining its Euro—Atlantic direction, in particular in the security and defence domain. In the run—up to the parliamentary election, I urge the Georgian authorities to ensure its free, fair and transparent character. I also appeal to them to free Giorgi Rurua, thus fulfilling the 8 March agreement reached with all the opposition leaders.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would like to begin by thanking Mr Mikser for his comprehensive report. I am pleased that there is a broad consensus in the assessment of Georgia's development here in the House. In Georgia, there is a broad political consensus on the country's European orientation. Unlike Russia, the EU also has something positive to offer.  Nevertheless, as in most transition states, the political landscape is very polarized and marked by mutual mistrust. This is not conducive to the domestic political atmosphere or to rapprochement with the EU. It is therefore extremely welcome that all the major parties have agreed on the joint declaration of 8 March, which agreed on a new electoral system, in line with the recommendations of the Venice Commission. I would like to take this opportunity to thank our Ambassador Hartzell and his team in particular for their contribution.  I hope that the election campaign and the election on 31 October will be used by all those responsible in the spirit of fairness in the application of the new legal framework. If the media fairly reflect the diversity of political opinions, if the election observers have the impression that the citizens have been able to cast their votes in a well-informed manner and that the electoral authority is beyond any doubt that it is acting impartially, then that would be a good day for the country and its future.

name: Nacho SÁNCHEZ AMOR
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank, like the rest of your honourable Members, the excellent work of Sven Mikser. We welcome Georgia's return to the path of reform which has made it, as some of the honourable Members have said, one of the countries in the area that is most close to European standards, after overcoming a double crisis, which has been overcome by dialogue and negotiation and, at this point, I also recognise the work of the European External Action Service and Ambassador Hartzell to manage this agreement with the opposition.  We regret that the opposition did not support constitutional reform and electoral reform in Parliament, despite its commitments and despite the pardons that took place, which were one of its requests. We were very demanding with the Government and very demanding with the majority party and believe that the opposition should have supported these reforms, that they were the continuation of the political agreement to which the European Union contributed and which, moreover, benefit, by losing the majority bias, those minor parties in the system.  In any case, with this new framework the elections move forward. And the concern now, Mr Borrell, is how we are going to observe an election in a pandemic situation, with difficulties on the part of Parliament and with difficulty in articulating a mission of the usual ones. I just heard that the OSCE is sending a normal electoral mission. I believe that the European Union, the European External Action Service and Parliament must do the same and we must in any case support domestic observation, because there are large NGOs working very professionally in that country. Because it is necessary to reassure the period immediately after the election, in a climate as polarized as it is traditional in Georgia and, for that, an international observation has always been essential. So that Georgia can continue on that path that we have all praised, in the direction of European values.

name: Helmut GEUKING
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Last year, I was able to travel to Georgia with the delegation. I was amazed at how quickly the state reacted: I got the list handed over with the 85 detainees, within 24 hours that was settled – 81 were free, and four were indicted, but also rightly indicted for attempting to overthrow by force of arms. So Georgia, I mean, was very flexible.  We had mentioned the right to vote. It should be changed in 2024. It was amended, as we all know, in March. So these are all signs that Georgia desperately wants to go to Europe, and rather yesterday than today. In other words, it is in our hands that we bring Georgia into our House of Europe as soon as possible. Because we are all aware of the situation with Russia, we see it in Crimea, with Ukraine, with Russia, in part, and we know about the occupied territories also in Georgia. Europe now has a duty here. We should now bring Georgia to Europe as soon as possible and really make it a full member. Georgia is ready. That is why it is up to us to take action here after the elections in October and to say that Georgia will become a full member of the European Union. That is what I would like to see, so that the country has a proper perspective. It has developed so well that it is now our turn to take this last step, and not just an agreement.

name: Josep BORRELL FONTELLES
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, honourable Members are right that these are crucial times for Georgia to demonstrate the maturity of its democracy. I have also been in Georgia in difficult times, much more difficult than now. The country is demonstrating democratic strength and economic development, and I think that we have to welcome that this Parliament will be stepping up its cooperation with the Georgian Parliament after the next elections and will also not shy away from reminding Georgia of the need to deliver on the full reform agenda. The problems at their borders should not be an excuse for not solving the problems in the interior of the country that only the Georgian people can solve. The European Union, through our Association Agreement, will continue supporting Georgia in this endeavour.

name: Kati PIRI
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Madam President, [inaudible] to close today’s plenary. This debate clearly demonstrates that Georgia has made substantial progress on its European path. This Parliament acknowledges the reforms on the part of the Georgian Government which strengthen democracy, the rule of law, human rights and fundamental freedoms, and of course, we also know work is still to be done.  Let me just highlight two items that require Georgia’s continued commitment. First and absolutely core in the implementation of the Association Agreement is the need for the Georgian Government to consolidate the rule of law and to continue its pursuit of justice reform. Second, and crucial to Georgia’s adherence to the terms in the Association Agreement, is guaranteeing media freedom. We all know that Georgia’s media landscape is highly politicised and as we are here speaking on Georgia ahead of the national elections, we also know the great responsibility that lies on the shoulders of all the political parties in Georgia to ensure a free and fair election.  Let me conclude with some positive words, with some words of support. Georgia is a country close to my heart. Some of my best friends live in that country and the country has come a long way in its aspirations for democracy, freedom and prosperity, and that in a very difficult geopolitical environment. The EU must recognise this and continue to be a key motivator for reforms to continue. I think we all agree that the Georgian people deserve no less.

name: Ewa KOPACZ
text: I close the debate. The amendments will be voted on on Tuesday 15 September 2020 and the final vote will take place on Wednesday 16 September 2020.
